Boundedness of Semistable Sheaves

Assjock
Algebraic Geometry Algebraic Geometry

发布于：Aug 24, 2024

19.2k words

119 min

本文为2024年暑假我于HKUST作的summer research program报告chaoshubiji. 在此我希望对港科的Li Weiping老师表示由衷的感谢. Li教授在代数几何方面学问广博, 平易近人, 他的教学深明大义, 向我揭示了模空间这一宏伟理论的一隅. 我因为水平有限, 难以形成自己的成果, 只能抄书作为报告, 实在惭愧.

以下是introduction 的部分简译:

模空间的存在性长期以来都作为代数几何的研究热点. 我们对是否存在一类能够"参数化"几何对象的空间感兴趣, 更进一步的, 如果这类空间存在, 它是否能够作为scheme? 它是否proper? coherent sheaf over XXX 的模空间 M\mathfrak{M}M 蕴含了许多XXX 本身的几何信息. 然而, M\mathfrak{M}M 并不总是存在. 许多情况下, 我们想要参数化的一族对象过"大", 导致 M\mathfrak{M}M 无法成为scheme, 因此我们希望研究有某些特殊性质的coherent sheaf 构成的模空间. 本文讨论的主要为具有固定的Hilbert polynomial 的一族torsion-free sheaf 形成的模空间. 而想要研究这一类模空间, 首先要解决的问题是F\mathfrak{F}F 这一族coherent sheaf是否有界, 也就是当模空间M\mathfrak{M}M存在时, 它是否是finite type over base field的.

Introduction

The existence of moduli space is one of the oldest and hottest topic in algebraic geometry. We are interested in if there exist a space that “parametrize” desired geometric objects, and if it exists, whether it’s proper or not. The moduli space M\mathfrak{M}M that parametrize coherent sheaves over algebraic varieties XXX encodes a lot of geometric information about XXX. However, such M\mathfrak{M}M does not always exist. Sometimes the family we want to parametrize is too “big” to make M\mathfrak{M}M into a scheme, so we may focus on a family F\mathfrak{F}F with specific property. In our case, we want to know some information about moduli space of torsion-free semistable sheaves with fixed Hilbert polynomial. To construct such a moduli space, the first and the most fundamental problem is the boundedness of the family F\mathfrak{F}F, i.e. the moduli space, if it exists, whether it is of finite type over the base field.

We will establish the bounded of torsion-free semistable sheaves with algebraically closed base field with characteristic zero following steps in Hu&Lehn7. We will begin with an introduction of μ\muμ-semistable sheaves and a complete proof of Kleiman’s criterion, which is an important criterion for boundedness. The second result is Grauert-Mülich Theorem. It describes the behaviour of semistable sheaf F\mathcal{F}F under restriction on general F\mathcal{F}F-regular sequences. Then we will discuss semistability of tensor product of sheaves and use it to prove the Le Potier-Simpson Theorem. We will also mention some approaches to the same problem in positive characteristic case in the last section.

Preliminaries

In this section, we set up the preliminaries for the semistable sheaves and boundedness of sheaves. For the part of of semistabilities, we refer Hu&Lehn7 for details and proofs. We will provide a useful criterion Theorem 17.

Let XXX be a projective variety over some algebraically closed field kkk. Fix an ample line sheaf OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1) and the corresponding ample divisor class HHH. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F, the dimension of F\mathcal{F}F is the dimension of SuppF\mathop{\mathrm{Supp}}\mathcal{F}SuppF, which is exactly the degree of Hilbert polynomial P(F)(m)P(\mathcal{F})(m)P(F)(m) with the respect to HHH. P(F)(m)P(\mathcal{F})(m)P(F)(m) can be expressed into the form ∑i=0dim⁡Fαi(F)mii!\sum\limits_{i=0}^{\dim\mathcal{F}}\alpha_{i}(\mathcal{F})\frac{m^{i}}{i!}i=0∑dimF​αi​(F)i!mi​ with rational coefficients.

Definition 1. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf of dimension d=dim⁡(X)d=\dim(X)d=dim(X), the degree of F\mathcal{F}F is defined by

deg⁡(F):=αd−1(F)−rk(F)⋅αd−1(OX)\deg(\mathcal{F}):= \alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{F})-\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\cdot \alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{X}) deg(F):=αd−1​(F)−rk(F)⋅αd−1​(OX​)

and its slope by

μ(F):=deg⁡(F)rk(F),\mu(\mathcal{F}):=\frac{\deg(\mathcal{F})}{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})}, μ(F):=rk(F)deg(F)​,

and the slope of Hilbert polynomial by

μ^(F):=αd−1(F)αd(F).\hat{\mu}(\mathcal{F}):=\frac{\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{F})}{\alpha_{d}(\mathcal{F})}. μ^​(F):=αd​(F)αd−1​(F)​.

Clearly, the relation of μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{F})μ(F) and μ(F)^\hat{\mu(\mathcal{F})}μ(F)^​ can be given by μ(F)=αd(OX)μ(F)^−αd−1(OX)\mu(\mathcal{F})=\alpha_{d}(\mathcal{O}_{X})\hat{\mu(\mathcal{F})}-\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{X})μ(F)=αd​(OX​)μ(F)^​−αd−1​(OX​). For smooth XXX, Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch Theorem shows that deg⁡F=c1(F)⋅Hd−1\deg \mathcal{F}=c_{1}(\mathcal{F})\cdot H^{d-1}degF=c1​(F)⋅Hd−1, which is an integer.

Definition 2. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf of dimension d=dim⁡(X)d=\dim(X)d=dim(X). F\mathcal{F}F is called μ\muμ-semistable (or just semistable) if any subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E has dimension less than ddd, then E\mathcal{E}E has dimension less than d−1d-1d−1, and for all subsheaf G⊂F\mathcal{G}\subset \mathcal{F}G⊂F with 0<rkG<rkF0<\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}\mathcal{G}<\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}\mathcal{F}0<rkG<rkF, we have μ(G)≤μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{G})\leq \mu(\mathcal{F})μ(G)≤μ(F). F\mathcal{F}F is called μ\muμ-stable if the above inequality is strict.

For torsion-free sheaf F\mathcal{F}F, the definition is equivalent to say: F\mathcal{F}F is (semi)stable if for all subsheaf G\mathcal{G}G of F\mathcal{F}F with 0<rk(G)<rk(F)0<\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{G})<\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})0<rk(G)<rk(F), μ(G)<μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{G})< \mu(\mathcal{F})μ(G)<μ(F) (resp. μ(G)≤μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{G})\leq \mu(\mathcal{F})μ(G)≤μ(F)). We will mainly focus on torsion-free semistable sheaves. An equivalent definition can be state in terms of quotient sheaves:

There’s another stablity called “Gieseker stablity”. The stablity involves pure sheaf:

Definition 3. A coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F is pure of dimension ddd if dim⁡F=d\dim \mathcal{F}=ddimF=d and all nontrivial coherent subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E of F\mathcal{F}F has dimension ddd.

Clearly, a sheaf F\mathcal{F}F is pure of dimension dim⁡X\dim XdimX is equivalent to F\mathcal{F}F is torsion free. Gieseker stablity encodes more information than μ\muμ-stablity. The coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F is (semi)stable if F\mathcal{F}F is pure and for all proper subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E, on has P(E)(m)αdim⁡E(E)(≤)P(F)(m)αdim⁡F(F)\frac{P(\mathcal{E})(m)}{\alpha_{\dim \mathcal{E}}(\mathcal{E})} (\leq )\frac{P(\mathcal{F})(m)}{\alpha_{\dim \mathcal{F}}(\mathcal{F})}αdimE​(E)P(E)(m)​(≤)αdimF​(F)P(F)(m)​.

Lemma 4. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf. Then F\mathcal{F}F is semistable if and only if for all quotient sheaves E\mathcal{E}E of F\mathcal{F}F, μ(E)≥μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{E})\geq \mu(\mathcal{F})μ(E)≥μ(F).

Proof

Proof. See Hu&Lehn7 section 1.2. ◻

The following lemma is useful in constructing Harder-Narasimhan filtration:

Lemma 5. Let F1\mathcal{F}_{1}F1​ and F2\mathcal{F}_{2}F2​ be semistable sheaves with μ(F1)>μ(F2)\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})>\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})μ(F1​)>μ(F2​), then Hom(F1,F2)=0\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(\mathcal{F}_{1},\mathcal{F}_{2})=0Hom(F1​,F2​)=0.

Proof

Proof. Loc.cit. ◻

The followings are some basic facts about semistability

Remark 6.

  1. A line sheaf L\mathcal{L}L is stable.

  2. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a semistable sheaf and L\mathcal{L}L a line sheaf, then F⊗L\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{L}F⊗L is semistable.

  3. Let 0→F′→F→F′′→00\to \mathcal{F}'\to \mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{F}''\to 00→F′→F→F′′→0 be a short exact sequence of sheaves. Then

  4. If F\mathcal{F}F is semistable and either μ(F)=μ(F′)\mu(\mathcal{F})=\mu(\mathcal{F}')μ(F)=μ(F′) or μ(F)=μ(F′′)\mu(\mathcal{F})=\mu(\mathcal{F}'')μ(F)=μ(F′′), then F′\mathcal{F}'F′ and F′′\mathcal{F}''F′′ are semistable.

  5. If F′\mathcal{F}'F′ and F′′\mathcal{F}''F′′ are semistable and μ(F′)=μ(F′′)\mu(\mathcal{F}')=\mu(\mathcal{F}'')μ(F′)=μ(F′′), then F\mathcal{F}F is
    semistable.

A torsion-free sheaf F\mathcal{F}F may not be semistable, but F\mathcal{F}F always admits a Harder-Narasimhan filtration whose factors are semistable. Harder-Narasimhan filtration is a very important tool in study of semistable sheaves.

Definition 7. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX. A Harder-Narasimhan filtration is an increasing filtration

0=HN0(F)⊂HN1(F)⊂⋯⊂HNl(F)=F,0=HN_{0}(\mathcal{F})\subset HN_{1}(\mathcal{F})\subset\cdots\subset HN_{l}(\mathcal{F})=\mathcal{F}, 0=HN0​(F)⊂HN1​(F)⊂⋯⊂HNl​(F)=F,

such that the factors griHN=HNi(F)/HNi−1(F)gr_{i}^{HN}=HN_{i}(\mathcal{F}) /HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})griHN​=HNi​(F)/HNi−1​(F) for i=1,…,li=1,\dots, li=1,…,l, are semistable sheaves with slope μi\mu_{i}μi​, satisfying

μmax:=μ1>μ2>⋯>μl=:μmin.\mu_{max}:=\mu_{1}>\mu_{2}>\cdots>\mu_{l}=:\mu_{min}. μmax​:=μ1​>μ2​>⋯>μl​=:μmin​.

We call gr1HNgr_{1}^{HN}gr1HN​ the maximal destablizing sheaf and grlHNgr_{l}^{HN}grlHN​ the minimal destablizing quotient. One can generalize Lemma 5 to torsion-free sheaves using notation above:

Lemma 8. Let F\mathcal{F}F and G\mathcal{G}G be torsion-free sheaves and μmin(F)>μmax(G)\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F})>\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmin​(F)>μmax​(G), then Hom(F,G)=0\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(\mathcal{F},\mathcal{G})=0Hom(F,G)=0.

Theorem 9. Every torsion-free sheaf F\mathcal{F}F has a unique Harder-Narasimhan filtration. Moreover, all factors of the Harder-Narasimhan filtration is torsion-free.

Proof

Proof. The idea is to find a subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E of F\mathcal{F}F such that for all subsheaf G⊂F\mathcal{G}\subset \mathcal{F}G⊂F, one has μ(E)≥μ(G)\mu(\mathcal{E})\geq \mu(\mathcal{G})μ(E)≥μ(G), and moreover, μ(E)=μ(G)\mu(\mathcal{E})=\mu(\mathcal{G})μ(E)=μ(G) only if G⊂E\mathcal{G}\subset\mathcal{E}G⊂E. Then we have E\mathcal{E}E unique and semistable. For more details, see Hu&Lehn7 section 1.3. ◻

Harder-Narasimhan filtration can be done on a family of sheaves parametrized on some integral scheme. For the proof we again refer to Hu&Lehn7 section 2.3. We explain some notation that will be used in the articles here:

For f:X→Sf:X\to Sf:X→S a morphism of finite type noetherian schemes an g:T→Sg:T\to Sg:T→S, the notation XTX_{T}XT​ will be used for the fibre product T×SXT\times_{S} XT×S​X, and gX:XT→Xg_{X}:X_{T}\to XgX​:XT​→X, fT:XT→Tf_{T}:X_{T}\to TfT​:XT​→T are the natural projections. For s∈Ss\in Ss∈S and coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, XsX_{s}Xs​ denotes the fibre f−1(s)=Speck(s)×SXf^{-1}(s)=\mathop{\mathrm{Spec}}k(s)\times_{S}Xf−1(s)=Speck(s)×S​X and Fs=F∣Xs\mathcal{F}_{s}=\mathcal{F}|_{X_{s}}Fs​=F∣Xs​​.

Theorem 10. *Let SSS be a finite type integral scheme over kkk. Let f:X→Sf:X\to Sf:X→S bea projective morphism and OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1) be an fff-ample line sheaf on XXX. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a flat family of coherent sheaves on the fibre of closed point on SSS. There is a projective birational morphism g:T→Sg:T\to Sg:T→S of integral kkk-scheme and a filtration

0=HN0(F)⊂HN1(F)⊂⋯⊂HNl(F)=gX∗F0=HN_{0}(\mathcal{F})\subset HN_{1}(\mathcal{F})\subset\cdots\subset HN_{l}(\mathcal{F})=g_{X}^{*}\mathcal{F} 0=HN0​(F)⊂HN1​(F)⊂⋯⊂HNl​(F)=gX∗​F

such that the following holds:*

  1. The factors HNi(F)/HNi−1(F)HN_{i}(\mathcal{F}) /HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})HNi​(F)/HNi−1​(F) are TTT-flat
    for all i=1,…,li=1,\dots, li=1,…,l;

  2. There is a dense open subscheme U⊂TU\subset TU⊂T such that
    HNi(F)t=gX∗HNi(Fg(t))HN_{i}(\mathcal{F})_{t}=g_{X}^{*}HN_{i}(\mathcal{F}_{g(t)})HNi​(F)t​=gX∗​HNi​(Fg(t)​) for all t∈Ut\in Ut∈U. Here HNi(F(g(t)))HN_{i}(\mathcal{F}_{(g(t))})HNi​(F(g(t))​) is the Harder-Narasimhan filtration of Fg(t)\mathcal{F}_{g(t)}Fg(t)​.

Remark 11.

  1. μmin(F⊕E)=min⁡{μmin(F),μmin(E)}\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}\oplus \mathcal{E})=\min\{\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}),\mu_{min}(\mathcal{E})\}μmin​(F⊕E)=min{μmin​(F),μmin​(E)};

  2. μmax(F⊕E)=max⁡{μmax(F),μmax(E)}\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}\oplus \mathcal{E})=\max\{\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}),\mu_{max}(\mathcal{E})\}μmax​(F⊕E)=max{μmax​(F),μmax​(E)}.

  3. μ(F⊗E)=μ(F)+μ(E)\mu(\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{E})=\mu(\mathcal{F})+\mu(\mathcal{E})μ(F⊗E)=μ(F)+μ(E).

  4. μmin(F⊗E)≤μmin(F)+μmin(E)\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{E})\leq \mu_{min}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{min}(\mathcal{E})μmin​(F⊗E)≤μmin​(F)+μmin​(E), μmax(F⊗E)≥μmax(F)+μmax(E)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{E})\geq \mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{E})μmax​(F⊗E)≥μmax​(F)+μmax​(E).

  5. For exact sequence 0→F′→F→F′′0\to \mathcal{F}'\to \mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{F}''0→F′→F→F′′, μmin(F)≥μmin(F′′)\mu_{min}(F)\geq \mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}'')μmin​(F)≥μmin​(F′′) and μmax(F)≥μmax(F′)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})\geq \mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}')μmax​(F)≥μmax​(F′).

To construct a moduli space of sheaves, we need to make sure that our family of sheaves is not too big to parametrize. We will prove this is true for semistable sheaves on kkk variety with chark=0\mathop{\mathrm{char}}k=0chark=0 in this report. We introduce the idea of boundedness and several criterion of boundedness next. The notation of Castelnuovo-Mumford regularity is needed.

Definition 12. Let m∈Zm\in \mathbb{Z}m∈Z and F\mathcal{F}F coherent sheaf on XXX. F\mathcal{F}F is mmm-regular if Hi(X,F(m−i))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-i))=0Hi(X,F(m−i))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0.

Lemma 13. If F\mathcal{F}F is mmm-regular, then the following facts holds:

  1. F\mathcal{F}F is m′m'm′-regular for all m′≥mm'\geq mm′≥m.

  2. F(m)\mathcal{F}(m)F(m) is generated by global sections.

  3. The natural evaluation homomorphism H0(X,F(m))⊗H0(X,O(n))→H0(X,F(m+n))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\otimes H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}(n))\to H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m+n))H0(X,F(m))⊗H0(X,O(n))→H0(X,F(m+n)) are surjective for all n≥0n\geq 0n≥0.

Proof

Proof. Follow the idea in Mum12. Without losing of generality we can assume X=PdX=\mathbb{P}^{d}X=Pd. kkk is algebraically closed so we can find a hyperplane section HHH which does not contain any of the associated points of F\mathcal{F}F. Then the sequence $$0\to \mathcal{F}(n-1)\to\mathcal{F}(n)\to \mathcal{F}_{H}(n)\to 0$$ is exact.

For 1, the long exact sequence gives Hi(X,F(n−i−1))→Hi(X,F(n−i))→Hi(H,FH(n−i))H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(n-i-1))\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(n-i))\to H^{i}(H,\mathcal{F}_{H}(n-i))Hi(X,F(n−i−1))→Hi(X,F(n−i))→Hi(H,FH​(n−i)). Proceeding a induction on nnn, we may assume Hi(X,F(n−i−1))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(n-i-1))=0Hi(X,F(n−i−1))=0. Similarly, by induction on the dimension ddd, we may assume Hi(H,FH(n))=0H^{i}(H,\mathcal{F}_{H}(n))=0Hi(H,FH​(n))=0. So Hi(X,F(n−i))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(n-i))=0Hi(X,F(n−i))=0. This shows F\mathcal{F}F is m′m'm′-regular for m′≥mm'\geq mm′≥m.

For 3, we only prove the case n=1n=1n=1, the general cases are similar. We use induction on ddd. Consider the commutative diagram

The top morphism is the tensor product of two surjective morphism so it’s surjective. By inductive hypothesis, τ\tauτ is also surjective, so ν∘μ\nu\circ \muν∘μ is surjective and H0(X,F(m+1))=imμ+kerνH^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m+1))=\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\mu+\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}\nuH0(X,F(m+1))=imμ+kerν. The bottom row is exact, we also have H0(X,F(m+1))=imμ+imαH^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m+1))=\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\mu+\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\alphaH0(X,F(m+1))=imμ+imα. Note that α\alphaα is given by tensoring the local section defining HHH, so imα⊂imμ\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\alpha\subset \mathop{\mathrm{im}}\muimα⊂imμ. So H0(X,F(m+1))=imμH^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m+1))=\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\muH0(X,F(m+1))=imμ.

For 2, take sufficiently large nnn, F(n)\mathcal{F}(n)F(n) is generated by global sections. Note H0(X,F(m))⊗H0(X,O(n−m))→H0(X,F(n))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\otimes H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}(n-m))\to H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(n))H0(X,F(m))⊗H0(X,O(n−m))→H0(X,F(n)) is surjective, F(n)\mathcal{F}(n)F(n) is generated by H0(X,F(m))⊗H0(X,O(n−m))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\otimes H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}(n-m))H0(X,F(m))⊗H0(X,O(n−m)). At any point p∈Xp\in Xp∈X, the local case of above surjection shows that F(m)p=F(n)p\mathcal{F}(m)_{p}=\mathcal{F}(n)_{p}F(m)p​=F(n)p​ is generated by H0(X,F(m))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))H0(X,F(m)). So F(m)\mathcal{F}(m)F(m) is generated by H0(X,F(m))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))H0(X,F(m)). ◻

Thanks to 1 in Lemma 13, we can define the regularity of a coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F to be reg(F):=inf⁡{m∈Z∣F is m-regular}\mathop{\mathrm{reg}}(\mathcal{F}):=\inf\{m\in \mathbb{Z}|\mathcal{F}\text{ is } m\text{-regular}\}reg(F):=inf{m∈Z∣F is m-regular}. Now we give the definition for boundedness of a family of sheaves.

Definition 14. A family F\mathfrak{F}F of isomorphism class of coherent sheaves on XXX is bounded if there is a kkk-scheme SSS of finite type and a coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on X×SX\times SX×S, such that F\mathfrak{F}F is the subset of {Fs∣s is closed point in S}\{\mathcal{F}_{s} | s\text{ is closed point in }S\}{Fs​∣s is closed point in S}.

Lemma 15. The following property of a family of sheaves {Fi}i∈I\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}_{i\in I}{Fi​}i∈I​ are equivalent:

  1. The family is bounded.

  2. The set of Hilbert polynomial {P(Fi)(m)}i∈I\{P(\mathcal{F}_{i})(m)\}_{i\in I}{P(Fi​)(m)}i∈I​ is finite and there is a uniform bound reg(Fi)≤ρ\mathop{\mathrm{reg}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})\leq \rhoreg(Fi​)≤ρ for all i∈Ii\in Ii∈I.

  3. The set of Hilbert polynomial {P(Fi)(m)}i∈I\{P(\mathcal{F}_{i})(m)\}_{i\in I}{P(Fi​)(m)}i∈I​ is finite and there is a coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F such that all Fi\mathcal{F}_{i}Fi​ admit a surjection F→Fi\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{F}_{i}F→Fi​ for all i∈Ii\in Ii∈I.

Proof

Proof. 1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 2: The finiteness of Hilbert polynomial is from the flatten stratification lemma (c.f. Hu&Lehn7 section 2.1). For the regularity part, note SSS is quasicompact and we may reduce to the case SSS is affine. There is a m>0m>0m>0 such that Hi(X×S,F(n))=0H^{i}(X\times S,\mathcal{F}(n))=0Hi(X×S,F(n))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0 and n>mn>mn>m. On the fibre Hi(X,F∣Speck(s)×X(m+d−i))=Hi(X×S,F)×k(s)=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}|_{\mathop{\mathrm{Spec}}k(s)\times X}(m+d-i))=H^{i}(X\times S,\mathcal{F})\times k(s)=0Hi(X,F∣Speck(s)×X​(m+d−i))=Hi(X×S,F)×k(s)=0, here d=dim⁡Xd=\dim Xd=dimX. Thus reg(Fi)≤m+d\mathop{\mathrm{reg}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})\leq m+dreg(Fi​)≤m+d.

2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3: Lemma 13 shows Fi(ρ)\mathcal{F}_{i}(\rho)Fi​(ρ) are generated by global sections, so there’s surjections O(−ρ)m→Fi\mathcal{O}(-\rho)^{m}\to \mathcal{F}_{i}O(−ρ)m→Fi​ with m≥max⁡{P(Fi)(ρ)}m\geq \max\{P(\mathcal{F}_{i})(\rho)\}m≥max{P(Fi​)(ρ)}. We will need the finiteness of the set {P(Fi)(m)}\{P(\mathcal{F}_{i})(m)\}{P(Fi​)(m)} here.

3 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 1: There’re only finitely many Hilbert polynomials. Let S=∐QuotP(Fi)S=\coprod\mathrm{Quot}_{P(\mathcal{F}_{i})}S=∐QuotP(Fi​)​ be the disjoint union of the Quot scheme corresponding to those finitely many Hilbert polynomials. Then 1 is immediate from the definition of Quot scheme. ◻

The following proposition allows us to estimate the regularity of a coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F in terms of Hilbert polynomial and the number of global sections of the restriction of F\mathcal{F}F to regular sequence of hyperplane sections.

Proposition 16. There’re universal polynomials Pi∈Q[T0,…,Ti]P_{i}\in \mathbb{Q}[T_{0},\dots, T_{i}]Pi​∈Q[T0​,…,Ti​] such that the following holds: Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf of dimension dim⁡(F)≤d\dim(\mathcal{F})\leq ddim(F)≤d and let H1,…,HdH_{1},\dots, H_{d}H1​,…,Hd​ be an regular sequence of hyperplane sections. If χ(F∣∩j≤iHj)=ai\chi(\mathcal{F}|_{\cap_{j\leq i}H_{j}})=a_{i}χ(F∣∩j≤i​Hj​​)=ai​ and h0(F∣∩j≤iHj)≤bih^{0}(\mathcal{F}|_{\cap_{j\leq i}}H_{j})\leq b_{i}h0(F∣∩j≤i​​Hj​)≤bi​, then $$\mathop{\mathrm{reg}}(\mathcal{F})\leq P_{d}(a_{0}-b_{0},\dots, a_{d}-b_{d}).$$

Proof

Proof. It suffices to show for the case X=PdX=\mathbb{P}^{d}X=Pd and dim⁡F=d\dim\mathcal{F}=ddimF=d. By the argument of Lemma 1.2.1 in Hu&Lehn7, the Hilbert polynomial P(F)(m)P(\mathcal{F})(m)P(F)(m) can be written into ∑i=0dai(m+i−1i)\sum\limits_{i=0}^{d}a_{i}\binom{m+i-1}{i}i=0∑d​ai​(im+i−1​). The proof proceed by induction on the dimension of the sheaf.

The base case is clear: for zero dimension sheaf, P0P_{0}P0​ can be taken as any polynomial.

Let d≥1d\geq 1d≥1, take any hyperplane scetion HHH which does not meet any associated points of F\mathcal{F}F, we have the exact sequence

0→F(m−1)→F(m)→FH(m)→00\to \mathcal{F}(m-1)\to \mathcal{F}(m)\to \mathcal{F}_{H}(m)\to 00→F(m−1)→F(m)→FH​(m)→0

and the long exact sequence

⋯→Hi(X,F(m−1))→Hi(X,F(m))→Hi(H,FH(m))→Hi+1(X,F(m−1))→⋯\cdots\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-1))\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\to H^{i}(H, \mathcal{F}_{H}(m))\to H^{i+1}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-1))\to \cdots⋯→Hi(X,F(m−1))→Hi(X,F(m))→Hi(H,FH​(m))→Hi+1(X,F(m−1))→⋯

By induction hypothesis, F∣H\mathcal{F}|_{H}F∣H​ is n=Pd−1(a1−b1,…,ad−bd)n=P_{d-1}(a_{1}-b_{1},\dots, a_{d}-b_{d})n=Pd−1​(a1​−b1​,…,ad​−bd​)-regular. For m≥n−1m\geq n-1m≥n−1, the long exact sequence and Lemma 13 shows that Hi(X,F(m))≅Hi(X,F(m−1))H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\cong H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-1))Hi(X,F(m))≅Hi(X,F(m−1)) for all i≥2i\geq 2i≥2, m≥n−2m\geq n-2m≥n−2. For sufficiently large mmm, the cohomologies vanishes so all Hi(X,F(m))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))=0Hi(X,F(m))=0 for i≥2i\geq 2i≥2, m≥n−2m\geq n-2m≥n−2. We also get a surjection

ν:H1(X,F(m−1))→H1(X,F(m)),\nu: H^{1}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-1))\to H^{1}(X,\mathcal{F}(m)),ν:H1(X,F(m−1))→H1(X,F(m)),

the function h1(F(m))h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(m))h1(F(m)) is decreasing in mmm. ν\nuν becomes an isomorphism if and only if the homomorphism H0(X,F(m))→H0(H,FH(m))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\to H^{0}(H,\mathcal{F}_{H}(m))H0(X,F(m))→H0(H,FH​(m)) is surjective. Use the same diagram as in the proof of Lemma 13, we can conclude that if H0(X,F(m))→H0(H,FH(m))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\to H^{0}(H,\mathcal{F}_{H}(m))H0(X,F(m))→H0(H,FH​(m)) is surjective, then H0(X,F(m+1))→H0(H,FH(m+1))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m+1))\to H^{0}(H,\mathcal{F}_{H}(m+1))H0(X,F(m+1))→H0(H,FH​(m+1)) is surjective. Once h1(F(m))=h1(F(m+1))h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(m))=h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(m+1))h1(F(m))=h1(F(m+1)), the value never decreases anymore. So h1(F(m))h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(m))h1(F(m)) strictly decrease to 0. For m≥n+h1(F(n))+1m\geq n+h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(n))+1m≥n+h1(F(n))+1, H1(X,F(m−1))=0H^{1}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-1))=0H1(X,F(m−1))=0.

Now we estimate the upper bound for h1(F(n))h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(n))h1(F(n)) by a polynomial in ai−bia_{i}-b_{i}ai​−bi​.

h1(F(n))=h0(F(n))−χ(F(n))=h0(F(n))−∑i=0dai(n+i−1i)h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(n))=h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(n))-\chi(\mathcal{F}(n))=h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(n))-\sum\limits_{i=0}^{d}a_{i}\binom{n+i-1}{i}h1(F(n))=h0(F(n))−χ(F(n))=h0(F(n))−i=0∑d​ai​(in+i−1​)

and

h0(F(n))≤∑i=0dbi(n+i−1i)h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(n))\leq \sum_{i=0}^{d}b_{i}\binom{n+i-1}{i}h0(F(n))≤i=0∑d​bi​(in+i−1​)

can be done inductively:

h0(F(n))≤h0(F(n−1))+h0(FH(n))h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(n))\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(n-1))+h^{0}(\mathcal{F}_{H}(n))h0(F(n))≤h0(F(n−1))+h0(FH​(n))

and h0(FH(n))≤∑i=1dbi(n+i−2i−1)h^{0}(\mathcal{F}_{H}(n))\leq \sum\limits_{i=1}^{d}b_{i}\binom{n+i-2}{i-1}h0(FH​(n))≤i=1∑d​bi​(i−1n+i−2​) implies h0(F(n))≤∑i=0dbi(n+i−1i)h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(n))\leq \sum\limits_{i=0}^{d}b_{i}\binom{n+i-1}{i}h0(F(n))≤i=0∑d​bi​(in+i−1​). So h1(F(n))≤∑i=0d(ai−bi)(n+i−1i)h^{1}(\mathcal{F}(n))\leq \sum\limits_{i=0}^{d}(a_{i}-b_{i})\binom{n+i-1}{i}h1(F(n))≤i=0∑d​(ai​−bi​)(in+i−1​), where n=Pd−1(a1−b1,…,ad−bd)n=P_{d-1}(a_{1}-b_{1},\dots, a_{d}-b_{d})n=Pd−1​(a1​−b1​,…,ad​−bd​). We may take Pd(a0−b0,…,ad−bd)=n+∑i=0d(ai−bi)(n+i−1i)P_{d}(a_{0}-b_{0},\dots, a_{d}-b_{d}) = n+\sum\limits_{i=0}^{d}(a_{i}-b_{i})\binom{n+i-1}{i}Pd​(a0​−b0​,…,ad​−bd​)=n+i=0∑d​(ai​−bi​)(in+i−1​). ◻

Combining Lemma 13 and Proposition 16, we get the important criterion for boundedness.

Theorem 17 (Kleiman Criterion). Let {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} be a family of coherent sheaf on XXX with the same Hilbert polynomial PPP. Then this family is bounded if and only if there are constants CiC_{i}Ci​, i=0,…,d=deg⁡(P)i=0,\dots, d=\deg(P)i=0,…,d=deg(P), such that for every Fi\mathcal{F}_{i}Fi​ there exists an Fi\mathcal{F}_{i}Fi​ regular sequence of hyperplane sections H1,…,HdH_{1},\dots, H_{d}H1​,…,Hd​ such that h0(F∣∩j≤i)≤Cih^{0}(\mathcal{F}|_{\cap j\leq i})\leq C_{i}h0(F∣∩j≤i​)≤Ci​.

Example 18. Let XXX be a smooth projective curve over algebraically closed field kkk. If {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} is a family of coherent sheaves with h0(Fi)h^{0}(\mathcal{F}_{i})h0(Fi​) and rk(Fi)\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})rk(Fi​), then {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} is bounded. This is because h0(Fi∣H)=rk(F)⋅deg⁡Xh^{0}(\mathcal{F}_{i}|_{H})=\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\cdot \deg Xh0(Fi​∣H​)=rk(F)⋅degX is bounded.

If {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} is a family of semistable sheaves with fixed Hilbert polynomial, then {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} is bounded.

Grauert-Mülich Theorem

To make a use of Kleiman criterion, we first need to understand the behaviour of semistable sheaves under the restriction to some hypersurface sections. Although for general hypersurface HHH, the restriction of semistable sheaf F\mathcal{F}F may not be semistable, F∣H\mathcal{F}|_{H}F∣H​ cannot be so ‘far’ from semistable. The first thing we need to prove is Grauert-Mülich theorem. We begin with some set up on incidence structures.

Let kkk be algebraically field of characteristic zero. Let XXX be a normal projective variety over kkk of dim⁡X≥2\dim X\geq 2dimX≥2 and fix a very ample sheaf O(1)\mathcal{O}(1)O(1) on XXX. Denote the linear system ∣O(a)∣\left| \mathcal{O}(a) \right|∣O(a)∣ by Πa\Pi_{a}Πa​ and let Za={(D,x)∈Πa×X∣x∈D}Z_{a}=\{(D,x)\in \Pi_{a}\times X|x\in D\}Za​={(D,x)∈Πa​×X∣x∈D} be the incidence variety. We also allow the incidence structures on different linear systems: Let Π=Πa1×⋯×Πal\Pi=\Pi_{a_{1}}\times \cdots\times \Pi_{a_{l}}Π=Πa1​​×⋯×Πal​​ and Z=Za1×X⋯×XZalZ=Z_{a_{1}}\times_{X}\cdots\times_{X} Z_{a_{l}}Z=Za1​​×X​⋯×X​Zal​​. Then there are natural projection p:Z→Πp:Z\to \Pip:Z→Π and q:Z→Xq:Z\to Xq:Z→X.

Let Va=H0(X,O(a))V_{a}=H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}(a))Va​=H0(X,O(a)) and K\mathcal{K}K be the kernel of the natural evaluation map Va⊗OX→OX(a)V_{a}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(a)Va​⊗OX​→OX​(a). Then Za=P(Kˇ)Z_{a}=\mathbb{P}(\check{\mathcal{K}})Za​=P(Kˇ) and there’s a natural closed immersion Za→P(Vˇ)×XZ_{a}\to \mathbb{P}(\check{V})\times XZa​→P(Vˇ)×X. qqq is the bundle morphism and therefore open. We can compute the relation tangent bundle by Euler sequence:

0→OZa→q∗K⊗p∗O(1)→TZa/X→00\to \mathcal{O}_{Z_{a}}\to q^{*}\mathcal{K}\otimes p^{*}\mathcal{O}(1)\to \mathcal{T}_{Z_{a}/X}\to 0 0→OZa​​→q∗K⊗p∗O(1)→TZa​/X​→0

ZZZ parametrizes the intersection of element in Πai\Pi_{a_{i}}Πai​​ in such a way: For s=(s1,s2,…,sl)s=(s_{1},s_{2},\dots, s_{l})s=(s1​,s2​,…,sl​) be a closed point in Π\PiΠ. Each sis_{i}si​ corresponds to a divisor DiD_{i}Di​. Then the fibre p−1(s)p^{-1}(s)p−1(s) can be identified by qqq with the scheme-theoretic intersection D1∩D2∩⋯∩Dl⊂XD_{1}\cap D_{2}\cap \cdots\cap D_{l}\subset XD1​∩D2​∩⋯∩Dl​⊂X. The relative tangent bundle of ZZZ can be similarly computed as TZ/X=p1∗TZa1/X⊕⋯⊕pl∗TZal/X\mathcal{T}_{Z/X}=p_{1}^{*}\mathcal{T}_{Z_{a_{1}} /X}\oplus\cdots\oplus p_{l}^{*}\mathcal{T}_{Z_{a_{l}} /X}TZ/X​=p1∗​TZa1​​/X​⊕⋯⊕pl∗​TZal​​/X​, where pi:Z→Zaip_{i}:Z\to Z_{a_{i}}pi​:Z→Zai​​ are the natural projections. For a coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, let E=q∗F\mathcal{E}=q^{*}\mathcal{F}E=q∗F, from the construction we have Es=F∣Zs\mathcal{E}_{s}=\mathcal{F}|_{Z_{s}}Es​=F∣Zs​​.

Lemma 19. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a torsion free coherent sheaf on XXX and E≅q∗F\mathcal{E}\cong q^{*}\mathcal{F}E≅q∗F. Then

There is a nonempty open subset S′⊂ΠS'\subset \PiS′⊂Π such that the morphism pS′:ZS′→S′p_{S'}:Z_{S'}\to S'pS′​:ZS′​→S′ is flat and for all s∈S′s\in S's∈S′, the fibre Zs=p−1(s)Z_{s}=p^{-1}(s)Zs​=p−1(s) is a normal irreducible complete intersection of codimension lll in XXX.

There is a nonempty dense open subset S⊂S′S\subset S'S⊂S′ such that the family ES=q∗F∣ZS\mathcal{E}_{S}=q^{*}\mathcal{F}|_{Z_{S}}ES​=q∗F∣ZS​​ is flat over SSS and for all s∈Ss\in Ss∈S, the fibre Es\mathcal{E}_{s}Es​ is torsion free.

Proof

Proof. The flatness is a generic condition. The remaining part follows from Bertini theorem, see Ha6 section 2.8.

The flatness is same as above. We reduce to the case of XXX smooth first. Let f:X→Pnf:X\to \mathbb{P}^{n}f:X→Pn be the closed immersion defining O(1)\mathcal{O}(1)O(1). We can regard F\mathcal{F}F as a pure sheaf of dimension dim⁡X\dim XdimX supported on XXX. Let S′′S''S′′ be the open subset which contains point sss that parametrizes regular sequence for F\mathcal{F}F and Exti(F,ωX)\mathcal{E}xt^{i}(\mathcal{F},\omega_{X})Exti(F,ωX​), ∀i≥0\forall i\geq 0∀i≥0. Then clearly S′′S''S′′ is not empty. Let S=S′′∩SS=S''\cap SS=S′′∩S. On each Zs=p−1(s)Z_{s}=p^{-1}(s)Zs​=p−1(s), the torsion-freeness is from the following lemma:

Lemma 20 (Hu&Lehn7). Let XXX be a smooth projective variety over kkk. For a coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F of codimension ccc, we say F\mathcal{F}F satisfies Serre condition Sk,cS_{k,c}Sk,c​ if depthFx≥min⁡{k,dim⁡OX,x−c}\mathop{\mathrm{depth}}\mathcal{F}_{x}\geq \min\{k,\dim\mathcal{O}_{X,x}-c\}depthFx​≥min{k,dimOX,x​−c} for all x∈Supp(F)x\in \mathop{\mathrm{Supp}}(\mathcal{F})x∈Supp(F). Then

  1. F\mathcal{F}F is pure if and only if F\mathcal{F}F satisfies S1,cS_{1,c}S1,c​.

  2. Let HHH be a hypersurface defined by some ample line sheaf L\mathcal{L}L. If HHH is a F\mathcal{F}F regular section and F\mathcal{F}F satisfies Sk,cS_{k,c}Sk,c​, then F∣H\mathcal{F}|_{H}F∣H​ satisfies Sk−1,c+1S_{k-1,c+1}Sk−1,c+1​.

Use the lemma and induction, one can easily see F∣Zs\mathcal{F}|_{Z_{s}}F∣Zs​​ satisfies S1,n−dim⁡X+lS_{1,n-\dim X+l}S1,n−dimX+l​, which means F∣Zs\mathcal{F}|_{Z_{s}}F∣Zs​​ is pure of dimension dim⁡X−l\dim X-ldimX−l and thus torsion free on ZsZ_{s}Zs​. ◻

We may shrink to a smaller open dense set SSS such that all the factors are flat. SSS is irreducible and thus connected, so μ((Ei/Ei−1)s)\mu((\mathcal{E}_{i}/\mathcal{E}_{i-1})_{s})μ((Ei​/Ei−1​)s​) is a constant for each s∈Ss\in Ss∈S. We may define μi=μ((Ei/Ei−1)s)\mu_{i}=\mu((\mathcal{E}_{i}/\mathcal{E}_{i-1})_{s})μi​=μ((Ei​/Ei−1​)s​). Then

μ1>μ2>⋯>μj−1.\mu_{1}>\mu_{2}>\cdots>\mu_{j-1}. μ1​>μ2​>⋯>μj−1​.

Define the number of gap by

δμ={0 if Es is semistablemax⁡{μi−μi+1} otherwise\delta\mu=\left\{\begin{aligned} &0 &&\text{ if }\mathcal{E}_{s} \text{ is semistable}\\ &\max\{\mu_{i}-\mu_{i+1}\} &&\text{ otherwise} \end{aligned}\right.δμ={​0max{μi​−μi+1​}​​ if Es​ is semistable otherwise​

The Grauert-Mülich theorem gives us an upper bound δμ\delta\muδμ for sufficient general s∈Ss\in Ss∈S.

Theorem 21 (Grauert-Mülich). Let F\mathcal{F}F be a semistable torsion-free sheaf. Then there is a nonempty open dense subset SSS of Π\PiΠ such that for all s∈Ss\in Ss∈S, the following inequality holdes:

δμ(F∣Zs)≤max⁡{ai}⋅∏i=1lai⋅deg⁡X.\delta\mu(\mathcal{F}|_{Z_{s}})\leq \max\{a_{i}\}\cdot\prod_{i=1}^{l} a_{i}\cdot \deg X. δμ(F∣Zs​​)≤max{ai​}⋅i=1∏l​ai​⋅degX.

Proof

Proof. The case Es\mathcal{E}_{s}Es​ is semistable is trivial. Assume δμ>0\delta\mu>0δμ>0 and δμ=μi−μi+1\delta \mu= \mu_{i}-\mu_{i+1}δμ=μi​−μi+1​ for specific iii and let E′=Ei\mathcal{E}'=\mathcal{E}_{i}E′=Ei​, E′′=E/E′\mathcal{E}''=\mathcal{E} /\mathcal{E}'E′′=E/E′. For all s∈Ss\in Ss∈S, Es′\mathcal{E}_{s}'Es′​ and Es′′\mathcal{E}_{s}''Es′′​ are torsion free and from the uniqueness of Harder-Narasimhan filtration, μmin(Es′)=μi\mu_{min}(\mathcal{E}_{s}')=\mu_{i}μmin​(Es′​)=μi​ and μmax(Es′′)=μi+1\mu_{max}(\mathcal{E}_{s}'')=\mu_{i+1}μmax​(Es′′​)=μi+1​.

Since torsion-free sheaves are locally free on a open subset, we may let Z0Z_{0}Z0​ be the maximal open subset of ZSZ_{S}ZS​ such that E∣Z0\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}E∣Z0​​ and E′′∣Z0\mathcal{E}''|_{Z_{0}}E′′∣Z0​​ are locally free. Let their ranks be rrr and r′′r''r′′, respectively. The surjection EZ0→EZ0′′\mathcal{E}_{Z_{0}}\to \mathcal{E}_{Z_{0}}''EZ0​​→EZ0​′′​ gives a morphism φ:Z0→Grass(F,r′′)\varphi:Z_{0}\to \mathop{\mathrm{Grass}}(\mathcal{F},r'')φ:Z0​→Grass(F,r′′), and E∣Z0→E∣Z0\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}\to \mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}E∣Z0​​→E∣Z0​​ is the pullback of F→U\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{U}F→U. Let X0X_{0}X0​ be the image of Z0Z_{0}Z0​ in XXX, since q:Z→Xq:Z\to Xq:Z→X is the bundle morphism, X0X_{0}X0​ is open. Note F\mathcal{F}F is torsion free, for any s∈Ss\in Ss∈S the complement of Z0∩ZsZ_{0}\cap Z_{s}Z0​∩Zs​ in ZsZ_{s}Zs​ has codimension larger than 111, the codimension of complement of X0X_{0}X0​ in XXX is also larger than 111.

Let

Dφ:TZ/X∣Z0→φ∗TGrass(F,r′′)/XD\varphi:\mathcal{T}_{Z/X}|_{Z_{0}}\to \varphi^{*}\mathcal{T}_{\mathop{\mathrm{Grass}}(\mathcal{F},r'') /X}Dφ:TZ/X​∣Z0​​→φ∗TGrass(F,r′′)/X​

be the relative differential morphism related to φ\varphiφ. Since TGrass(F,r′′)/X=Hom(ker(F→U),U)\mathcal{T}_{\mathop{\mathrm{Grass}}(\mathcal{F},r'') /X}=\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{U}),\mathcal{U})TGrass(F,r′′)/X​=Hom(ker(F→U),U), we can identify φ∗TGrass(F,r′′)/X\varphi^{*}\mathcal{T}_{\mathop{\mathrm{Grass}}(\mathcal{F},r'') /X}φ∗TGrass(F,r′′)/X​ as Hom(φ∗ker(F→U),φ∗U)=Hom(E∣Z0′,E∣Z0′′)\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\varphi^{*}\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{U}),\varphi^{*}\mathcal{U})=\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}',\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}'')Hom(φ∗ker(F→U),φ∗U)=Hom(E∣Z0​′​,E∣Z0​′′​). Thus DφD\varphiDφ corresponds to

Φ:(E′⊗TZ/X)∣Z0→E∣Z0′′\Phi:(\mathcal{E}'\otimes \mathcal{T}_{Z /X})|_{Z_{0}}\to \mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}''Φ:(E′⊗TZ/X​)∣Z0​​→E∣Z0​′′​

via the isomorphism Hom((E′⊗TZ/X)∣Z0,E∣Z0′′)≅Hom(TZ/X∣Z0,Hom(E∣Z0′,E∣Z0′′))\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}((\mathcal{E}'\otimes \mathcal{T}_{Z /X})|_{Z_{0}},\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}'')\cong \mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(\mathcal{T}_{Z /X}|_{Z_{0}},\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}',\mathcal{E}|_{Z_{0}}''))Hom((E′⊗TZ/X​)∣Z0​​,E∣Z0​′′​)≅Hom(TZ/X​∣Z0​​,Hom(E∣Z0​′​,E∣Z0​′′​)).

Next we want to show Φs≠0\Phi_{s}\neq 0Φs​=0 for general s∈Ss\in Ss∈S. Suppose on the contrary. We may shrink SSS smaller if necessary to make Φ=0\Phi=0Φ=0. Since qqq is faithfully flat, according to Theorem 40, E∣X0\mathcal{E}|_{X_{0}}E∣X0​​ is also locally free. Restricting φ\varphiφ to Z0Z_{0}Z0​, we have the following diagram:

q0q_{0}q0​ is a smooth morphism with connected fibres. If Φ=0\Phi=0Φ=0, then Dφ=0D\varphi=0Dφ=0 and in characteristic zero case, this will imply φ\varphiφ is constant on fibre of q0q_{0}q0​. Then by rigidity lemma, there is a morphism ρ:X0→Grass(F∣X0,r′′)\rho:X_{0}\to \mathop{\mathrm{Grass}}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{0}},r'')ρ:X0​→Grass(F∣X0​​,r′′). From the universal property of Grass(F∣X0,r′′)\mathop{\mathrm{Grass}}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{0}},r'')Grass(F∣X0​​,r′′), there’s a quotient F∣X0→F′′\mathcal{F}|_{X_{0}}\to \mathcal{F}''F∣X0​​→F′′ of rank r′′r''r′′. Moreover, F∣X0∩Zs′′≅Es′′∣Z0∩Zs\mathcal{F}|_{X_{0}\cap Z_{s}}''\cong \mathcal{E}''_{s}|_{Z_{0}\cap Z_{s}}F∣X0​∩Zs​′′​≅Es′′​∣Z0​∩Zs​​ for general s∈Ss\in Ss∈S. Since F∣X0\mathcal{F}|_{X_{0}}F∣X0​​ is support on codimension ≥2\geq 2≥2 sets in XXX, any extension F′′′\mathcal{F}'''F′′′ of F′′\mathcal{F}''F′′ to XXX satisfies μ(F′′′)=μ(F′′)\mu(\mathcal{F}''')=\mu(\mathcal{F}'')μ(F′′′)=μ(F′′). By our assumption, Es′′\mathcal{E}_{s}''Es′′​ is a destablizing quotient of Es\mathcal{E}_{s}Es​, this means F′′′\mathcal{F}'''F′′′ is destablizing quotient of F\mathcal{F}F. This contradicts the assumption that F\mathcal{F}F is semistable.

A nontrivial Φs\Phi_{s}Φs​ defines a morphism Es′⊗TZ/X∣Zs\mathcal{E}_{s}'\otimes \mathcal{T}_{Z /X}|_{Z_{s}}Es′​⊗TZ/X​∣Zs​​ to Es′′\mathcal{E}_{s}''Es′′​ in the quotient category Cohn−l,n−l−1(Zs)\mathop{\mathrm{Coh}}_{n-l,n-l-1}(Z_{s})Cohn−l,n−l−1​(Zs​). Then by Lemma 5, we have the inequality

μmin(Es′⊗TZ/X∣Zs)≤μmax(Es′′).\mu_{min}(\mathcal{E}_{s}'\otimes \mathcal{T}_{Z /X}|_{Z_{s}})\leq \mu_{max}(\mathcal{E}_{s}'').μmin​(Es′​⊗TZ/X​∣Zs​​)≤μmax​(Es′′​).

Consider the Koszul complex associated to the evaluation map e:Va⊗OX→O(a)e:V_{a}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}\to \mathcal{O}(a)e:Va​⊗OX​→O(a). Taking the last terms, we get a surjection ∧2Va⊗OX(−a)→ker(e)=K\wedge^{2} V_{a}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(-a)\to \mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(e)=\mathcal{K}∧2Va​⊗OX​(−a)→ker(e)=K and hence a surjection

∧2Va⊗q∗OX(−a)⊗p∗O(1)→q∗K⊗p∗O(1)→TZa/X.\wedge^{2}V_{a}\otimes q^{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(-a)\otimes p^{*}\mathcal{O}(1)\to q^{*}\mathcal{K}\otimes p^{*}\mathcal{O}(1)\to \mathcal{T}_{Z_{a} /X}.∧2Va​⊗q∗OX​(−a)⊗p∗O(1)→q∗K⊗p∗O(1)→TZa​/X​.

Using TZ/X=⨁ipi∗TZai/X\mathcal{T}_{Z /X}=\bigoplus\limits_{i} p_{i}^{*}\mathcal{T}_{Z_{a_{i}} /X}TZ/X​=i⨁​pi∗​TZai​​/X​, we have a surjection

(⨁i∧2Vai⊗O(−ai))∣Zs→TZ/X∣Zs.(\bigoplus_{i}\wedge^{2} V_{a_{i}}\otimes \mathcal{O}(-a_{i}))|_{Z_{s}}\to \mathcal{T}_{Z /X}|_{Z_{s}}.(i⨁​∧2Vai​​⊗O(−ai​))∣Zs​​→TZ/X​∣Zs​​.

Therefore,

μmin(Es′⊗TZ/X∣Zs)≥μmin(⨁i∧2Vai⊗O(−ai)⊗E′∣Zs)=min⁡i{μmin(OZs(−ai)⊗Es′)}=μmin(Es′)−max⁡{ai}⋅deg⁡(Zs).\begin{aligned} \mu_{min}(\mathcal{E}_{s}'\otimes\mathcal{T}_{Z /X}|_{Z_{s}})&\geq \mu_{min}(\bigoplus_{i}\wedge^{2}V_{a_{i}}\otimes \mathcal{O}(-a_{i})\otimes \mathcal{E}'|_{Z_{s}})\\&=\min\limits_{i}\{\mu_{min}(\mathcal{O}_{Z_{s}(-a_{i})}\otimes \mathcal{E}_{s}')\}\\&=\mu_{min}(\mathcal{E}_{s}')-\max\{a_{i}\}\cdot\deg(Z_{s}).\end{aligned}μmin​(Es′​⊗TZ/X​∣Zs​​)​≥μmin​(i⨁​∧2Vai​​⊗O(−ai​)⊗E′∣Zs​​)=imin​{μmin​(OZs​(−ai​)​⊗Es′​)}=μmin​(Es′​)−max{ai​}⋅deg(Zs​).​

In conclusion,

δμ=μi−μi+1=μmin(Fs′)−μmax(Fs′′)≤max⁡{ai}⋅deg⁡(Zs)=max⁡{ai}⋅∏ai⋅deg⁡(X).\begin{aligned} \delta\mu=\mu_{i}-\mu_{i+1}&=\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}_{s}')-\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}_{s}'')\\&\leq \max\{a_{i}\}\cdot \deg(Z_{s})\\&=\max\{a_{i}\}\cdot \prod a_{i}\cdot \deg(X).\end{aligned}δμ=μi​−μi+1​​=μmin​(Fs′​)−μmax​(Fs′′​)≤max{ai​}⋅deg(Zs​)=max{ai​}⋅∏ai​⋅deg(X).​

Corollary 22. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a torsion-free semistable sheaf of rank rrr on XXX. Let YYY be the intersection of s<dim⁡Xs<\dim Xs<dimX general hyperplanes in ∣OX(1)∣\left| \mathcal{O}_{X}(1) \right|∣OX​(1)∣. Then

μmin(F∣Y)≥μ(F)−r−12deg⁡(X)\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}|_{Y})\geq \mu(\mathcal{F})-\frac{r-1}{2}\deg(X) μmin​(F∣Y​)≥μ(F)−2r−1​deg(X)

and

μmax(F∣Y)≤μ(F)+r−12deg⁡(X).\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}|_{Y})\leq \mu(\mathcal{F})+\frac{r-1}{2}\deg(X). μmax​(F∣Y​)≤μ(F)+2r−1​deg(X).

Proof

Proof. We only show the inequality for μmax\mu_{max}μmax​, μmin\mu_{min}μmin​ is similar. If F∣Y\mathcal{F}|_{Y}F∣Y​ is semistable then there’s nothing to prove. Let μ1,…,μj\mu_{1},\dots, \mu_{j}μ1​,…,μj​ and r1,…,rjr_{1},\dots,r_{j}r1​,…,rj​ be the slopes and ranks of the factors of the Harder-Narasimhan filtration of F∣Y\mathcal{F}|_{Y}F∣Y​. Note all the rir_{i}ri​ are positive integers since the factors are torsion-free. By Theorem 21, we have $$\mu_{i}-\mu_{i+1}\leq \deg X.$$ Take the sum from 1 to iii we get μi≥μ1−(i−1)deg⁡X\mu_{i}\geq \mu_{1}-(i-1)\deg Xμi​≥μ1​−(i−1)degX. So

μ(F)=∑i=1jrirμi≥μ1−deg⁡Xr∑i=1j(i−1)ri≥μ1−deg⁡Xr∑i=1r(i−1)=μmax(F∣Y)−deg⁡X⋅r−12.\begin{aligned} \mu(\mathcal{F})&= \sum_{i=1}^{j}\frac{r_{i}}{r}\mu_{i}\\& \geq \mu_{1}-\frac{\deg X}{r}\sum_{i=1}^{j}(i-1)r_{i}\\& \geq \mu_{1}-\frac{\deg X}{r}\sum_{i=1}^{r}(i-1)\\& = \mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}|_{Y})-\deg X\cdot\frac{r-1}{2}. \end{aligned}μ(F)​=i=1∑j​rri​​μi​≥μ1​−rdegX​i=1∑j​(i−1)ri​≥μ1​−rdegX​i=1∑r​(i−1)=μmax​(F∣Y​)−degX⋅2r−1​.​
