Semistability and Tensor Products

One thing we need to prove in this section is tensor product preserves semistability. The proof involves Theorem 21 and ampleness of positive degree sheaves, which become true only in characteristic zero case. We need to first figure out the behaviour of semistable sheaves under pullback and pushforward via finite morphisms.

Let f:Y→Xf:Y\to Xf:Y→X be a finite morphism of normal projective varieties over kkk of dimension nnn. Fix an ample line sheaf OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1), then OY(1)=f∗OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{Y}(1)=f^{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OY​(1)=f∗OX​(1) is also ample. fff is affine morphism so all the higher direct image vanishes, and Hi(X,f∗F)=Hi(Y,F)H^{i}(X,f_{*}\mathcal{F})=H^{i}(Y,\mathcal{F})Hi(X,f∗​F)=Hi(Y,F). In particular, the Hilbert polynomial P(F)(m)=P(f∗F)(m)P(\mathcal{F})(m)=P(f_{*}\mathcal{F})(m)P(F)(m)=P(f∗​F)(m) and therefore f∗f_{*}f∗​ preserves the dimension of sheaves.

Let A\mathcal{A}A be the sheaf of algebras f∗OYf_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}f∗​OY​, then A\mathcal{A}A is a torsion-free coherent sheaf of rank ddd. f∗f_{*}f∗​ gives an equivalence between the category of coherent sheaves on YYY and the category of coherent sheaves on XXX with A\mathcal{A}A-module structure. A\mathcal{A}A is torsion-free and thus locally free in codimension 1, which means fff is flat in codimension 1. f∗f^{*}f∗ is exact functor from the quotient category Cohn,n−1(X)\mathrm{Coh}_{n,n-1}(X)Cohn,n−1​(X) to Cohn,n−1(Y)\mathrm{Coh}_{n,n-1}(Y)Cohn,n−1​(Y).

For a pure sheaf F\mathcal{F}F of dimension mmm, suppose there’s a nnn-dimensional quotient G\mathcal{G}G of f∗Ff_{*}\mathcal{F}f∗​F. G\mathcal{G}G admits a natural A\mathcal{A}A-module structure, so there’s a coherent OY\mathcal{O}_{Y}OY​-module G′\mathcal{G}'G′, which is a mmm-dimensional quotient of F\mathcal{F}F. This contradicts the assumption that F\mathcal{F}F is pure. Therefore f∗f_{*}f∗​ preserves the purity of sheaves.

Assume F\mathcal{F}F is pure of dimension nnn which is torsion-free in codimension 1 in Coh(X)\mathrm{Coh}(X)Coh(X). Since deg⁡(f∗F)=ddeg⁡(F)\deg(f^{*}\mathcal{F})=d\deg(\mathcal{F})deg(f∗F)=ddeg(F) and rk(f∗F)=rk(F)\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(f^{*}\mathcal{F})=\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})rk(f∗F)=rk(F), μ(f∗F)=dμ(F)\mu(f^{*}\mathcal{F})=d\mu(\mathcal{F})μ(f∗F)=dμ(F).

Assume G\mathcal{G}G is pure of dimension nnn which is torsion-free in codimension 1 in Coh(Y)\mathrm{Coh}(Y)Coh(Y). Then c1(OY(1))n=d⋅c1(OX(1))nc_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{Y}(1))^{n}=d\cdot c_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(1))^{n}c1​(OY​(1))n=d⋅c1​(OX​(1))n and deg⁡Y=ddeg⁡X\deg Y=d\deg XdegY=ddegX. Since P(G)(m)=P(f∗G)(m)P(\mathcal{G})(m)=P(f_{*}\mathcal{G})(m)P(G)(m)=P(f∗​G)(m), we have rk(f∗G)=drk(G)\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(f_{*}\mathcal{G})=d\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{G})rk(f∗​G)=drk(G). Note that

deg⁡(A)=αd−1(OY)−rk(A)αd−1(OX)=αd−1(OY)−d⋅αd−1OX,\deg(\mathcal{A})=\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{Y})-\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{X})=\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{Y})-d\cdot \alpha_{d-1}\mathcal{O}_{X}, deg(A)=αd−1​(OY​)−rk(A)αd−1​(OX​)=αd−1​(OY​)−d⋅αd−1​OX​,

deg⁡(G)=αd−1(G)−rk(G)αd−1(OY)=αd−1(f∗G)−rk(f∗G)αd−1(OX)−rk(G)deg⁡(A).\deg(\mathcal{G})=\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{G})-\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{G})\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{Y})=\alpha_{d-1}(f_{*}\mathcal{G})-\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(f_{*}\mathcal{G})\alpha_{d-1}(\mathcal{O}_{X})-\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{G})\deg(\mathcal{A}). deg(G)=αd−1​(G)−rk(G)αd−1​(OY​)=αd−1​(f∗​G)−rk(f∗​G)αd−1​(OX​)−rk(G)deg(A).

We have μ(G)=d(μ(f∗G)−μ(A))\mu(\mathcal{G})=d(\mu(f_{*}\mathcal{G})-\mu(\mathcal{A}))μ(G)=d(μ(f∗​G)−μ(A)).

In characteristic zero case, we have the following lemma:

Lemma 23. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a nnn-dimensional coherent sheaf on XXX. Then F\mathcal{F}F is semistable if and only if f∗Ff^{*}\mathcal{F}f∗F is semistable.

Proof

Proof. F\mathcal{F}F is torsion-free in codimension 1 if and only if f∗Ff^{*}\mathcal{F}f∗F is torsion-free, so we are allowed to work in the category Cohn,n−1(Y)\mathrm{Coh}_{n,n-1}(Y)Cohn,n−1​(Y).

We first show the if direction: Suppose there is subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E of F\mathcal{F}F such that μ(E)>μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{E})>\mu(\mathcal{F})μ(E)>μ(F), then μ(f∗E)>μ(F)\mu(f^{*}\mathcal{E})>\mu(\mathcal{F})μ(f∗E)>μ(F). This leads to a contradiction.

Then we show the only if direction: Let KKK be the splitting field of the function field K(Y)K(Y)K(Y) over K(X)K(X)K(X). Let ZZZ be the normalization of YYY in KKK, then we have finite morphisms Z→Y→XZ\to Y\to XZ→Y→X. By pulling back f∗Ff^{*}\mathcal{F}f∗F to ZZZ, we may consider the finite morphism g:Z→Xg:Z\to Xg:Z→X. Note that K(Z)K(Z)K(Z) is Galois over K(X)K(X)K(X), Z→XZ\to XZ→X is a Galois cover with Galois group GGG. Suppose g∗Fg^{*}\mathcal{F}g∗F is not semistable and it’s maximal destablizing sheaf E\mathcal{E}E. Since E\mathcal{E}E is unique, it’s invariant under the action of GGG. By Theorem 43, there’s a coherent subsheaf F′⊂F\mathcal{F}'\subset \mathcal{F}F′⊂F such that f∗F′f^{*}\mathcal{F}'f∗F′ isomorphic to E\mathcal{E}E in codimension 1. Then μ(F′)>μ(F)\mu(\mathcal{F}')>\mu(\mathcal{F})μ(F′)>μ(F) and we have a contradiction. ◻

We will omit the proof of the next lemma here and refer to Ma11.

Lemma 24. Let XXX be a projective normal variety over algebraically closed field kkk and let OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1) be a very ample line sheaf. For integer ddd there exist a projective normal variety X′X'X′ with very ample line sheaf OX′(1)\mathcal{O}_{X'}(1)OX′​(1) and a finite morphism f:X′→Xf:X'\to Xf:X′→X such that f∗OX(1)≅OX′(d)f^{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)\cong \mathcal{O}_{X'}(d)f∗OX​(1)≅OX′​(d). Moreover, if XXX is smooth, X′X'X′ can be chosen to be smooth.

Proof

Proof. See Corollary 1.15.1 in Ma11. ◻

Using above lemmas and results in Appendix B, we are able to prove the theorem:

Theorem 25. Let XXX be a normal projective variety over an algebraically closed field of characteristic zero. If F1\mathcal{F}_{1}F1​ and F2\mathcal{F}_{2}F2​ are semistable sheaves, then F1⊗F2\mathcal{F}_{1}\otimes \mathcal{F}_{2}F1​⊗F2​ is semistable.

Proof

Proof. Suppose on the contrary. Let E\mathcal{E}E be a torsion-free destablizing quotient of F1⊗F2\mathcal{F}_{1}\otimes \mathcal{F}_{2}F1​⊗F2​. We first reduce to the case that μ(F1)+μ(F2)−μ(E)\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})-\mu(\mathcal{E})μ(F1​)+μ(F2​)−μ(E) is large enough case. Using Lemma 24, there’s a finite morphism f:X′→Xf:X'\to Xf:X′→X such that f∗OX(1)≅OX′(d)f^{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)\cong \mathcal{O}_{X'}(d)f∗OX​(1)≅OX′​(d) for large ddd. μ(f∗E)\mu(f^{*}\mathcal{E})μ(f∗E) are defined with respect to OX′(1)\mathcal{O}_{X'}(1)OX′​(1). f∗F1f^{*}\mathcal{F}_{1}f∗F1​ and f∗F2f^{*}\mathcal{F}_{2}f∗F2​ are also semistable by Lemma 23, and f∗Ef^{*}\mathcal{E}f∗E is a torsion free destablizing quotient of f∗(F1⊗F2)f^{*}(\mathcal{F}_{1}\otimes \mathcal{F}_{2})f∗(F1​⊗F2​). Take

d>⌈deg⁡X⋅(rk(F1)+rk(F2)+2)2(μ(F1)+μ(F2)−μ(E))⌉,d>\lceil{\frac{\deg X\cdot (\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{2})+2)}{2(\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})-\mu(\mathcal{E}))}}\rceil,d>⌈2(μ(F1​)+μ(F2​)−μ(E))degX⋅(rk(F1​)+rk(F2​)+2)​⌉,

we have

μ(f∗F1)+μ(f∗F2)−μ(f∗E)deg⁡X′=d⋅μ(F1)+μ(F2)−μ(E)deg⁡X>rk(F1)+rk(F2)+22=rk(f∗F1)+rk(f∗F2)−22.\begin{aligned} \frac{\mu(f^{*}\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mu(f^{*}\mathcal{F}_{2})-\mu(f^{*}\mathcal{E})}{\deg X'}&=d\cdot \frac{\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})-\mu(\mathcal{E})}{\deg X}\\ &> \frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{2})+2}{2}\\ &= \frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(f^{*}\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(f^{*}\mathcal{F}_{2})-2}{2}.\end{aligned}degX′μ(f∗F1​)+μ(f∗F2​)−μ(f∗E)​​=d⋅degXμ(F1​)+μ(F2​)−μ(E)​>2rk(F1​)+rk(F2​)+2​=2rk(f∗F1​)+rk(f∗F2​)−2​.​

So we may assume

μ(F1)+μ(F2)−μ(E)>deg⁡X⋅(rk(F1)+rk(F2)+2)2.\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})-\mu(\mathcal{E})>\frac{\deg X\cdot (\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{2})+2)}{2}.μ(F1​)+μ(F2​)−μ(E)>2degX⋅(rk(F1​)+rk(F2​)+2)​.

According to Bertini theorem, the complete intersection for general dim⁡X−1\dim X-1dimX−1 hyperplanes forms a smooth curve CCC. Applying Corollary 22, the Harder-Narasimhan factors satisfy

μ(grjHN(Fi∣C))≥μ(Fi)−deg⁡X⋅rk(Fi)−12\mu(gr_{j}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}_{i}|_{C}))\geq \mu(\mathcal{F}_{i})-\deg X\cdot \frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})-1}{2}μ(grjHN​(Fi​∣C​))≥μ(Fi​)−degX⋅2rk(Fi​)−1​

for each i=1,2i=1, 2i=1,2. Let

ni=⌈μ(Fi)deg⁡X−rk(Fi)−12⌉−1.n_{i}=\lceil{\frac{\mu(\mathcal{F}_{i})}{\deg X}-\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})-1}{2}}\rceil-1.ni​=⌈degXμ(Fi​)​−2rk(Fi​)−1​⌉−1.

Then

μ(grjHNFi(−ni)∣C)≥μ(Fi)−deg⁡X⋅(ni+rk(Fi)−12)>0.\mu(gr_{j}^{HN}\mathcal{F}_{i}(-n_{i})|_{C})\geq \mu(\mathcal{F}_{i})-\deg X\cdot (n_{i}+\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})-1}{2})>0.μ(grjHN​Fi​(−ni​)∣C​)≥μ(Fi​)−degX⋅(ni​+2rk(Fi​)−1​)>0.

Then grjHN(Fi(−ni)∣C)gr_{j}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}_{i}(-n_{i})|_{C})grjHN​(Fi​(−ni​)∣C​) is a semistable torsion-free sheaf on CCC and therefore a semistable vector bundle by 45. μ(grjHN(Fi(−ni)∣C))>0\mu(gr_{j}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}_{i}(-n_{i})|_{C}))>0μ(grjHN​(Fi​(−ni​)∣C​))>0 so by Theorem 50 grjHN(Fi(−ni)∣C)gr_{j}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}_{i}(-n_{i})|_{C})grjHN​(Fi​(−ni​)∣C​) is ample. According to Corollary 49, griHN(F1(−n1)∣C)⊗grjHN(F2(−n2)∣C)gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}_{1}(-n_{1})|_{C})\otimes gr_{j}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}_{2}(-n_{2})|_{C})griHN​(F1​(−n1​)∣C​)⊗grjHN​(F2​(−n2​)∣C​) is ample. Therefore by Proposition 47 (F1⊗F2)(−n1−n2)∣C(\mathcal{F}_{1}\otimes \mathcal{F}_{2})(-n_{1}-n_{2})|_{C}(F1​⊗F2​)(−n1​−n2​)∣C​ is also ample. E(−n1−n2)∣C\mathcal{E}(-n_{1}-n_{2})|_{C}E(−n1​−n2​)∣C​ as a quotient of ample vector bundle is also ample.

Note that

μ(E(−n1−n2))=μ(E)−(n1+n2)deg⁡X<μ(F1)+μ(F2)−deg⁡X⋅(n1+n2+rk(F1)+rk(F2)+22)=μ(F1)−deg⁡X⋅(rk(F1)−12+n1+1)+μ(F2)−deg⁡X⋅(rk(F2)−12+n2+1)≤0.\begin{aligned} \mu(\mathcal{E}(-n_{1}-n_{2}))&=\mu(\mathcal{E})-(n_{1}+n_{2})\deg X\\ &<\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})-\deg X\cdot (n_{1}+n_{2}+\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{1})+\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{2})+2}{2})\\ &=\mu(\mathcal{F}_{1})-\deg X\cdot (\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{1})-1}{2}+n_{1}+1)\\ &+\mu(\mathcal{F}_{2})-\deg X\cdot (\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{2})-1}{2}+n_{2}+1)\\ &\leq 0.\end{aligned}μ(E(−n1​−n2​))​=μ(E)−(n1​+n2​)degX<μ(F1​)+μ(F2​)−degX⋅(n1​+n2​+2rk(F1​)+rk(F2​)+2​)=μ(F1​)−degX⋅(2rk(F1​)−1​+n1​+1)+μ(F2​)−degX⋅(2rk(F2​)−1​+n2​+1)≤0.​

So deg⁡(E(−n1−n2)∣C)=deg⁡(E(−n1−n2))<0\deg(\mathcal{E}(-n_{1}-n_{2})|_{C})=\deg(\mathcal{E}(-n_{1}-n_{2}))<0deg(E(−n1​−n2​)∣C​)=deg(E(−n1​−n2​))<0, which contardicts the fact E(−n1−n2)∣C\mathcal{E}(-n_{1}-n_{2})|_{C}E(−n1​−n2​)∣C​ is ample. ◻

Corollary 26. Let F\mathcal{F}F and G\mathcal{G}G be torsion-free coherent sheaves on normal projective variety XXX. Then

  1. μmin(F⊗G)=μmin(F)+μmax(G)\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G})=\mu_{min}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmin​(F⊗G)=μmin​(F)+μmax​(G).

  2. μmax(F⊗G)=μmax(F)+μmax(G)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G})=\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmax​(F⊗G)=μmax​(F)+μmax​(G).

Proof

Proof. We only prove for μmax\mu_{max}μmax​. One direction is easy: As in Remark 11, pick the maximal destablizing sheaf F′\mathcal{F}'F′ and G′\mathcal{G}'G′ of F\mathcal{F}F, G\mathcal{G}G respectively. Then F′⊗G′\mathcal{F}'\otimes\mathcal{G}'F′⊗G′ destablizes F⊗G\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G}F⊗G and μ(F′)+μ(G′)=μmax(F)+μmax(G)\mu(\mathcal{F}')+\mu(\mathcal{G}')=\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μ(F′)+μ(G′)=μmax​(F)+μmax​(G). So μmax(F⊗G)≥μmax(F)+μmax(G)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G})\geq \mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmax​(F⊗G)≥μmax​(F)+μmax​(G).

For the other direction, F\mathcal{F}F and G\mathcal{G}G are locally free in codimension 1, we may work in the cateogory Cohdim⁡X,dim⁡X−1(X)\mathrm{Coh}_{\dim X,\dim X-1}(X)CohdimX,dimX−1​(X). First we prove for the case G\mathcal{G}G is semistable. Let griHN(F)=HNi(F)/HNi−1(F)gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F})=HN_{i}(\mathcal{F}) /HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})griHN​(F)=HNi​(F)/HNi−1​(F) be the Harder-Narasimhan filtration of F\mathcal{F}F. Then

0=HN0F⊗G⊂⋯⊂HNn(F)⊗G=F⊗G0=HN_{0}\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G}\subset \cdots\subset HN_{n}(\mathcal{F})\otimes \mathcal{G}=\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{G}0=HN0​F⊗G⊂⋯⊂HNn​(F)⊗G=F⊗G

gives a filtration of F⊗G\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{G}F⊗G with semistable factors and strictly decreasing slope. Thus the uniqueness of Harder-Narasimhan filtration shows that griHN(F)⊗Ggr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F})\otimes \mathcal{G}griHN​(F)⊗G gives a Harder-Narasimhan filtration of F⊗G\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G}F⊗G. HN0(F)⊗GHN_{0}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}HN0​(F)⊗G is the maximal destablizing sheaf of F⊗G\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G}F⊗G and μmax(F⊗G)=μmax(F)+μmax(G)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G})=\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmax​(F⊗G)=μmax​(F)+μmax​(G).

For general G\mathcal{G}G, we prove μmax(griHN(F)⊗G)=μmax(F)+μmax(G)\mu_{max}(gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G})=\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmax​(griHN​(F)⊗G)=μmax​(F)+μmax​(G) by induction on iii. The base case is from our discussion above. For i>1i>1i>1, consider the exact sequence

0→HNi−1(F)⊗G→HNi(F)⊗G→griHN(F)⊗G→00\to HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}\to HN_{i}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}\to gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}\to 00→HNi−1​(F)⊗G→HNi​(F)⊗G→griHN​(F)⊗G→0

in the category Cohdim⁡X,dim⁡X−1\mathrm{Coh}_{\dim X,\dim X-1}CohdimX,dimX−1​. Then by Remark 6,

μmax(HNi−1(F)⊗G)≤μmax(HNi(F)⊗G).\mu_{max}(HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G})\leq \mu_{max}(HN_{i}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}).μmax​(HNi−1​(F)⊗G)≤μmax​(HNi​(F)⊗G).

Let E\mathcal{E}E be the maximal destablizing sheaf of HNi(F)⊗GHN_{i}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}HNi​(F)⊗G. Let 0→E′→E→E′/E→00\to \mathcal{E}'\to \mathcal{E}\to \mathcal{E}' /\mathcal{E}\to 00→E′→E→E′/E→0 be the induced exact sequence by setting E′=E∩HNi−1(F)⊗G\mathcal{E}'=\mathcal{E}\cap HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}E′=E∩HNi−1​(F)⊗G, then E′/E\mathcal{E}' /\mathcal{E}E′/E is a subsheaf of griHN(F)⊗Ggr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}griHN​(F)⊗G. So we have

μmax(HNi(F⊗G))=μ(E)≤max⁡{μ(E),μ(E′/E)}≤max⁡{μmax(HNi−1(F)⊗G),μmax(griHN(F)⊗G)}=μmax(HNi−1(F)⊗G)\begin{aligned} \mu_{max}(HN_{i}(\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{G}))&=\mu(\mathcal{E}) \leq \max\{\mu(\mathcal{E}),\mu(\mathcal{E}' /\mathcal{E})\}\\ &\leq \max\{\mu_{max}(HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G}),\mu_{max}(gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G})\}\\ &=\mu_{max}(HN_{i-1}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G})\end{aligned}μmax​(HNi​(F⊗G))​=μ(E)≤max{μ(E),μ(E′/E)}≤max{μmax​(HNi−1​(F)⊗G),μmax​(griHN​(F)⊗G)}=μmax​(HNi−1​(F)⊗G)​

Thus μmax(HNi(F)⊗G)=μmax(F)+μmax(G)\mu_{max}(HN_{i}(\mathcal{F})\otimes\mathcal{G})=\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})+\mu_{max}(\mathcal{G})μmax​(HNi​(F)⊗G)=μmax​(F)+μmax​(G). ◻

Corollary 27. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a torsion-free semistable sheaf on XXX. Then all exterior products ∧nF\wedge^{n}\mathcal{F}∧nF, all symmetric products SnFS^{n}\mathcal{F}SnF and Hom(F,F)\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\mathcal{F},\mathcal{F})Hom(F,F) are semistable.

Proof

Proof. Let dim⁡X=d\dim X=ddimX=d. Note that ∧nF\wedge^{n}\mathcal{F}∧nF and SnFS^{n}\mathcal{F}SnF are all direct summands of F⊗n\mathcal{F}^{\otimes n}F⊗n. On can easily calculate that μ(F⊗n)=μ(∧nF)=μ(SnF)\mu(\mathcal{F}^{\otimes n})=\mu(\wedge^{n}\mathcal{F})=\mu(S^{n}\mathcal{F})μ(F⊗n)=μ(∧nF)=μ(SnF), so according to Remark 6, they are semistable.

We show that Fˇ\check{\mathcal{F}}Fˇ is semistable. Suppose there is a destablizing sheaf E\mathcal{E}E of Fˇ\check{\mathcal{F}}Fˇ. We may assume Fˇ/E\check{\mathcal{F}} /\mathcal{E}Fˇ/E is torsion-free, otherwise we may replace E\mathcal{E}E by its saturation in Fˇ\check{\mathcal{F}}Fˇ. Therefore Fˇ/E\check{\mathcal{F}} /\mathcal{E}Fˇ/E is locally free in codimension 1. Consider the exact sequence

0→E→Fˇ→Fˇ/E→00\to \mathcal{E}\to \check{\mathcal{F}}\to \check{\mathcal{F}} /\mathcal{E}\to 00→E→Fˇ→Fˇ/E→0

in Cohd,d−1(X)\mathrm{Coh}_{d,d-1}(X)Cohd,d−1​(X), it’s dual

0→(Fˇ/E)ˇ→F→Eˇ→00\to (\check{\mathcal{F}} /\mathcal{E})^{\check{}}\to \mathcal{F}\to \check{\mathcal{E}}\to 00→(Fˇ/E)ˇ→F→Eˇ→0

in Cohd,d−1(X)\mathrm{Coh}_{d,d-1}(X)Cohd,d−1​(X) is still exact. Then μ(E)>μ(Fˇ)\mu(\mathcal{E})>\mu(\check{\mathcal{F}})μ(E)>μ(Fˇ) implies μ(F)>μ(Eˇ)\mu(\mathcal{F})>\mu(\check{\mathcal{E}})μ(F)>μ(Eˇ), which contradict the assumption F\mathcal{F}F is semistable. In codimension 1 F\mathcal{F}F is locally free so Hom(F,F)\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\mathcal{F},\mathcal{F})Hom(F,F) is isomorphic to F⊗Fˇ\mathcal{F}\otimes\check{\mathcal{F}}F⊗Fˇ in Cohd,d−1(X)\mathrm{Coh}_{d,d-1}(X)Cohd,d−1​(X). Since F\mathcal{F}F and Fˇ\check{\mathcal{F}}Fˇ are semistable, Hom(F,F)\mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\mathcal{F},\mathcal{F})Hom(F,F) is semistable. ◻

Boundedness in Zero Characteristic

In this section, we will use Theorem 17 to show the boundedness of semistable sheaves with fixed Hilbert polynomial. The base field kkk is assumed to be algebraically closed with characteristic zero. Let [x]+=max⁡{x,0}[x]_{+}=\max\{x,0\}[x]+​=max{x,0} for any real number xxx.

We first deal with the case that XXX is normal.

Lemma 28. Let XXX be a normal projective variety of dimension ddd. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a torsion-free sheaf on XXX. Then for any F\mathcal{F}F-regular sequence of hyperplane sections H1,…,HdH_{1},\dots, H_{d}H1​,…,Hd​ and Xv=H1∩⋯∩Hd−vX_{v}=H_{1}\cap \cdots\cap H_{d-v}Xv​=H1​∩⋯∩Hd−v​ the following inequality holds for all v=1,…,dv=1,\dots, dv=1,…,d:

h0(Xv,F∣Xv)rk(F)⋅deg⁡X≤1v![μmax(F∣X1)deg⁡X+v]+v.\frac{h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})}{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\cdot \deg X}\leq \frac{1}{v!}\left[\frac{\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})}{\deg X}+v\right]_{+}^{v}. rk(F)⋅degXh0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​)​≤v!1​[degXμmax​(F∣X1​​)​+v]+v​.

Proof

Proof. The proof proceeds by induction on vvv. For the base case, let griHN(F∣X1)gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})griHN​(F∣X1​​), i=1,…,li=1,\dots, li=1,…,l be the Harder-Narasimhan filtration of F∣X1\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}}F∣X1​​. Taking the global sections one have

h0(X1,F∣X1)≤∑i=1lh0(X1,griHN(F∣X1)).h^{0}(X_{1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})\leq \sum_{i=1}^{l}h^{0}(X_{1},gr_{i}^{HN}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})).h0(X1​,F∣X1​​)≤i=1∑l​h0(X1​,griHN​(F∣X1​​)).

We may assume F∣X1\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}}F∣X1​​ is semistable and therefore μmax(F∣X1)=μ(F∣X1)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})=\mu(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})μmax​(F∣X1​​)=μ(F∣X1​​). For any n≥0n\geq 0n≥0, we can take F∣X1\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}}F∣X1​​-regular section HHH in OX1(n)\mathcal{O}_{X_{1}}(n)OX1​​(n) and an exact sequence

0→F∣X1(−n)→F∣X1→F∣X1∩H→00\to \mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}}(-n)\to \mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}}\to \mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}\cap H}\to 00→F∣X1​​(−n)→F∣X1​​→F∣X1​∩H​→0

So

h0(X1,F∣X1)≤h0(X1,F∣X1)+n⋅rk(F)⋅deg⁡Xh^{0}(X_{1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})\leq h^{0}(X_{1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})+n\cdot\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\cdot \deg Xh0(X1​,F∣X1​​)≤h0(X1​,F∣X1​​)+n⋅rk(F)⋅degX

For n≥⌈μ(F∣X1)deg⁡X⌉+1n\geq \lceil{\frac{\mu(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})}{\deg X}}\rceil+1n≥⌈degXμ(F∣X1​​)​⌉+1, we have h0(X1,F∣X1(−n))=hom(OX1(n),F∣X1)=0h^{0}(X_{1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}}(-n))=\mathop{\mathrm{hom}}(\mathcal{O}_{X_{1}}(n),\mathcal{F}|_{X_{1}})=0h0(X1​,F∣X1​​(−n))=hom(OX1​​(n),F∣X1​​)=0. Thus we get our desired upper bound.

Assume the inequality for v−1v-1v−1 with v≥2v\geq 2v≥2. Consider the exact
sequence

0→F∣Xv(−k−1)→F∣Xv(−k)→F∣Xv−1(−k)→00\to \mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}}(-k-1)\to \mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}}(-k)\to \mathcal{F}|_{X_{v-1}}(-k)\to 00→F∣Xv​​(−k−1)→F∣Xv​​(−k)→F∣Xv−1​​(−k)→0

for k=0,1,2,…k=0,1,2,\dotsk=0,1,2,…, inductively we have

h0(Xv,F∣Xv)≤h0(Xv,F∣Xv(−n))+∑k=0n−1h0(Xv−1,F∣Xv−1(−k))≤∑k=0∞h0(Xv−1,F∣Xv−1(−k)).\begin{aligned} h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})&\leq h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}}(-n))+\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}h^{0}(X_{v-1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v-1}}(-k))\\ &\leq \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}h^{0}(X_{v-1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v-1}}(-k)).\end{aligned}h0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​)​≤h0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​(−n))+k=0∑n−1​h0(Xv−1​,F∣Xv−1​​(−k))≤k=0∑∞​h0(Xv−1​,F∣Xv−1​​(−k)).​

Similarly, h0(Xv−1,F∣Xv−1(−k))h^{0}(X_{v-1},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v-1}}(-k))h0(Xv−1​,F∣Xv−1​​(−k)) vanishes for k>μmax(F∣Xv−1)k>\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v-1}})k>μmax​(F∣Xv−1​​) so the summation is actually finite. Using the induction hypothesis and replace the summation by integral, we have

h0(Xv,F∣Xv)rk(F)⋅deg⁡X≤1(v−1)!∫−1C[μmax(FX1)deg⁡X+v−1−t]+v−1dt\frac{h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})}{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\cdot \deg X}\leq \frac{1}{(v-1)!}\int_{-1}^{C}\left[\frac{\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F}_{X_{1}})}{\deg X}+v-1-t\right]_{+}^{v-1}dtrk(F)⋅degXh0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​)​≤(v−1)!1​∫−1C​[degXμmax​(FX1​​)​+v−1−t]+v−1​dt

where CCC is the maximum of -1 and the smallest zero of the integrand. By simple calculus we have the right hand side of the lemma. ◻

Using above lemma and Corollary 22, we immediately have

Corollary 29. Let XXX be a normal projective variety of dimension ddd and F\mathcal{F}F is torsion-free sheaf on XXX. For general hyperplanes H1,…,HdH_{1},\dots, H_{d}H1​,…,Hd​ in ∣OX(1)∣\left| \mathcal{O}_{X}(1) \right|∣OX​(1)∣, the following inequality holdes for all v=1,…,dv=1,\dots, dv=1,…,d:

h0(Xv,F∣Xv)rk(F)⋅deg⁡X≤1v![μmax(F)deg⁡X+rk(F)−12+v]+v.\frac{h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})}{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\cdot \deg X}\leq \frac{1}{v!}\left[\frac{\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})}{\deg X}+\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})-1}{2}+v\right]_{+}^{v}. rk(F)⋅degXh0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​)​≤v!1​[degXμmax​(F)​+2rk(F)−1​+v]+v​.

Corollary 29 gives a uniform bound for torsion-free semistable sheaves with fixed Hilbert polynomial (note μmax(F)=μ(F)\mu_{max}(\mathcal{F})=\mu(\mathcal{F})μmax​(F)=μ(F)) on normal projective variety. Combining it with 17, we get the boundedness for the specific case.

Theorem 30 (Le Potier-Simpson). Let XXX be a ddd-dimensional projective variety and F\mathcal{F}F be a torsion free sheaf on XXX. Let r(F)=αd(F)r(\mathcal{F})=\alpha_{d}(\mathcal{F})r(F)=αd​(F) be the multiplicity of F\mathcal{F}F. Then there is a F\mathcal{F}F-regular sequence of hyperplane sections H1,…,HdH_{1},\dots, H_{d}H1​,…,Hd​ and Xv=H1∩⋯∩Hd−vX_{v}=H_{1}\cap \cdots\cap H_{d-v}Xv​=H1​∩⋯∩Hd−v​ such that the following inequality holds for all v=1,…,dv=1,\dots, dv=1,…,d:

h0(Xv,F∣Xv)r(F)≤1v![μ^max(F)+r(F)2+r(F)+d2−1]+v\frac{h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})}{r(\mathcal{F})}\leq \frac{1}{v!}\left[\hat{\mu}_{max}(\mathcal{F})+r(\mathcal{F})^{2}+\frac{r(\mathcal{F})+d}{2}-1\right]_{+}^{v} r(F)h0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​)​≤v!1​[μ^​max​(F)+r(F)2+2r(F)+d​−1]+v​

Proof

Proof. Let i:X→PNi:X\to \mathbb{P}^{N}i:X→PN be the closed immersion corresponding to the very ample sheaf OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1). Consider a N−d−1N-d-1N−d−1-dimensional linear subspace L⊂PNL\subset \mathbb{P}^{N}L⊂PN which does not intersect XXX. Let π:PN−L→Y≅Pd\pi:\mathbb{P}^{N}-L\to Y\cong \mathbb{P}^{d}π:PN−L→Y≅Pd be the projection with center LLL, π\piπ is a finite morphism. Denote π∗OX\pi_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}π∗​OX​ by A\mathcal{A}A. π∗F\pi_{*}\mathcal{F}π∗​F is also torsion-free and r(F)=αd(π∗F)=rk(π∗F)r(\mathcal{F})=\alpha_{d}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})=\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})r(F)=αd​(π∗​F)=rk(π∗​F). We also have

μ^(F)=μ^(π∗F)=μ(π∗F)αd(OY)+μ^(OY)=μ(π∗F)+d+12.\hat{\mu}(\mathcal{F})=\hat{\mu}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})=\frac{\mu(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})}{\alpha_{d}(\mathcal{O}_{Y})}+\hat{\mu}(\mathcal{O}_{Y})=\mu(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})+\frac{d+1}{2}.μ^​(F)=μ^​(π∗​F)=αd​(OY​)μ(π∗​F)​+μ^​(OY​)=μ(π∗​F)+2d+1​.

A π∗F\pi_{*}\mathcal{F}π∗​F-regular sequence Hi′H_{i}'Hi′​ in Y≅PdY\cong \mathbb{P}^{d}Y≅Pd naturally induces an F\mathcal{F}F-regular sequence HiH_{i}Hi​ in XXX. Denote Yv=H1′∩⋯∩Hv′Y_{v}=H_{1}'\cap \cdots\cap H_{v}'Yv​=H1′​∩⋯∩Hv′​, then π∗(F∣Xv)=(π∗F)∣Yv\pi_{*}(\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})=(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})|_{Y_{v}}π∗​(F∣Xv​​)=(π∗​F)∣Yv​​. Apply Corollary 29 to π∗F\pi_{*}\mathcal{F}π∗​F, there is an inequality for v=1,…,dv=1,\dots,dv=1,…,d:

h0(Xv,F∣Xv)rk(π∗F)≤1v![μmax(π∗F)+rk(π∗F)−12+v]+v.\frac{h^{0}(X_{v},\mathcal{F}|_{X_{v}})}{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})}\leq \frac{1}{v!}\left[\mu_{max}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})+\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})-1}{2}+v\right]_{+}^{v}.rk(π∗​F)h0(Xv​,F∣Xv​​)​≤v!1​[μmax​(π∗​F)+2rk(π∗​F)−1​+v]+v​.

We need to estimate μmax(π∗F)\mu_{max}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})μmax​(π∗​F) by μ^max(π∗F)\hat{\mu}_{max}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})μ^​max​(π∗​F). First we show that μmin(A)≥−r(F)2\mu_{min}(\mathcal{A})\geq -r(\mathcal{F})^{2}μmin​(A)≥−r(F)2: Clearly A\mathcal{A}A is torsion-free sheaf. The injection A→Hom(π∗F,π∗F)\mathcal{A}\to \mathop{\mathcal{H}om}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F},\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})A→Hom(π∗​F,π∗​F) shows that rk(A)≤rk(π∗F)2=r(F)2\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})\leq \mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})^{2}=r(\mathcal{F})^{2}rk(A)≤rk(π∗​F)2=r(F)2. Let W=OY(−1)N−d\mathcal{W}=\mathcal{O}_{Y}(-1)^{N-d}W=OY​(−1)N−d, then XXX is a closed subscheme of the vector bundle π:PN−L≅SpecS∗W→Y\pi: \mathbb{P}^{N}-L\cong \mathop{\mathrm{Spec}}S^{*}W\to Yπ:PN−L≅SpecS∗W→Y, so there is a surjection φ:S∗W→A\varphi:S^{*}\mathcal{W}\to \mathcal{A}φ:S∗W→A. Consider the filtration of A\mathcal{A}A by ascending OY\mathcal{O}_{Y}OY​-modules

FiA=φ(OY⊕W⊕⋯⊕SiW)F_{i}\mathcal{A}=\varphi(\mathcal{O}_{Y}\oplus\mathcal{W}\oplus\cdots\oplus S^{i}\mathcal{W})Fi​A=φ(OY​⊕W⊕⋯⊕SiW)

Since A\mathcal{A}A is coherent, only finitely many factors griF(A)gr_{i}^{F}(\mathcal{A})griF​(A) are not zero. Since W⊗griF(A)→gri+1F(A)\mathcal{W}\otimes gr_{i}^{F}(\mathcal{A})\to gr_{i+1}^{F}(\mathcal{A})W⊗griF​(A)→gri+1F​(A) is surjective, once griF(A)gr_{i}^{F}(\mathcal{A})griF​(A) has torsion, all grjF(A)gr_{j}^{F}(\mathcal{A})grjF​(A) has torsion for j≥ij\geq ij≥i. If griF(A)gr_{i}^{F}(\mathcal{A})griF​(A) has no torsion then i≤rk(A)i\leq \mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})i≤rk(A), so the cokernel of φ:OY⊕W⊕⋯⊕Srk(A)W→A\varphi:\mathcal{O}_{Y}\oplus \mathcal{W}\oplus\cdots\oplus S^{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})}\mathcal{W}\to \mathcal{A}φ:OY​⊕W⊕⋯⊕Srk(A)W→A has torsion. Hence

μmin(A)≥μmin(Srk(A)W)=μ(Srk(A)W)=rk(A)μ(W)=−rk(A)\mu_{min}(\mathcal{A})\geq \mu_{min}(S^{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})}\mathcal{W})=\mu(S^{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})\mathcal{W}})=\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{A})\mu(\mathcal{W})=-rk(\mathcal{A})μmin​(A)≥μmin​(Srk(A)W)=μ(Srk(A)W)=rk(A)μ(W)=−rk(A)

and $$\mu_{min}(\mathcal{A})\geq -r(\mathcal{F})^{2}.$$

Let E\mathcal{E}E be the maximal destablizing sheaf of π∗F\pi_{*}\mathcal{F}π∗​F and E′\mathcal{E}'E′ be its image under the multiplication morphism A⊗E→A⊗π∗F→π∗E\mathcal{A}\otimes\mathcal{E}\to \mathcal{A}\otimes \pi_{*}\mathcal{F}\to \pi_{*}\mathcal{E}A⊗E→A⊗π∗​F→π∗​E. E′\mathcal{E}'E′ is the A\mathcal{A}A-submodule of π∗F\pi_{*}\mathcal{F}π∗​F generated by E\mathcal{E}E, and E′≅π∗E′′\mathcal{E}'\cong \pi_{*}\mathcal{E}''E′≅π∗​E′′ for some OX\mathcal{O}_{X}OX​-submodule E′′\mathcal{E}''E′′ of F\mathcal{F}F. So

μ^max(F)≥μ^(E′′)=μ^(E′)=μ(E′)+μ^(OY),\hat{\mu}_{max}(\mathcal{F})\geq \hat{\mu}(\mathcal{E}'')=\hat{\mu}(\mathcal{E}')=\mu(\mathcal{E}')+\hat{\mu}(\mathcal{O}_{Y}),μ^​max​(F)≥μ^​(E′′)=μ^​(E′)=μ(E′)+μ^​(OY​),

by Lemma 5,

μ(E′)+μ^(OY)≥μmin(A⊗E)+d+12\mu(\mathcal{E}')+\hat{\mu}(\mathcal{O}_{Y})\geq \mu_{min}(\mathcal{A}\otimes\mathcal{E})+\frac{d+1}{2}μ(E′)+μ^​(OY​)≥μmin​(A⊗E)+2d+1​

by Corollary 26,

μmin(A⊗E)+d+12=μ(E)+μmin(A)+d+12≥μmax(π∗F)−r(F)2+d+12.\begin{aligned} \mu_{min}(\mathcal{A}\otimes\mathcal{E})+\frac{d+1}{2}&=\mu(\mathcal{E})+\mu_{min}(\mathcal{A})+\frac{d+1}{2}\\ &\geq \mu_{max}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})-r(\mathcal{F})^{2}+\frac{d+1}{2}.\end{aligned}μmin​(A⊗E)+2d+1​​=μ(E)+μmin​(A)+2d+1​≥μmax​(π∗​F)−r(F)2+2d+1​.​

Therefore we have

μmax(π∗F)+rk(π∗F)−12+v≤μ^max(F)+r(F)2+r(F)−12+d−12.\mu_{max}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})+\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\pi_{*}\mathcal{F})-1}{2}+v \leq \hat{\mu}_{max}(\mathcal{F})+r(\mathcal{F})^{2}+\frac{r(\mathcal{F})-1}{2}+\frac{d-1}{2}.μmax​(π∗​F)+2rk(π∗​F)−1​+v≤μ^​max​(F)+r(F)2+2r(F)−1​+2d−1​.

◻

Theorem 31. Let XXX be a projective variety over kkk. The family of semistable sheaves on XXX with fixed Hilbert polynomial is bounded.

Proof

Proof. Immediate corollary from Theorem 17 and Theorem 30. ◻

Boundedness in General Characteristic

When XXX is a smooth projective curve over algebraically closed field kkk, the semistability of sheaves behave well in arbitrary characteristic.

Theorem 32. {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} is a family of semistable sheaves with fixed Hilbert polynomial, then {Fi}\{\mathcal{F}_{i}\}{Fi​} is bounded.

Proof

Proof. We show that there is an integer mmm such that Fi\mathcal{F}_{i}Fi​ is mmm-regular for all iii. Assume the Hilbert polynomial is given by P(n)=n⋅rk(Fi)⋅deg⁡(O(1))+deg⁡(Fi)+rk(Fi)(1−g)P(n)=n\cdot\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})\cdot\deg(\mathcal{O}(1))+\deg(\mathcal{F}_{i})+\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})(1-g)P(n)=n⋅rk(Fi​)⋅deg(O(1))+deg(Fi​)+rk(Fi​)(1−g), so all the sheaves have the same rank and degree. By Serre duality, H1(X,Fi(m−1))=Hom(Fi(m−1),ω)ˇH^{1}(X,\mathcal{F}_{i}(m-1))=\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(\mathcal{F}_{i}(m-1),\omega)^{\check{}}H1(X,Fi​(m−1))=Hom(Fi​(m−1),ω)ˇ. Note Fi(m−1)\mathcal{F}_{i}(m-1)Fi​(m−1) and ω\omegaω are all semistable. Set

m=⌈2rk(Fi)g(X)−2rk(Fi)−deg⁡(Fi)deg⁡(O(1))+1⌉m=\lceil{\frac{2\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})g(X)-2\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F}_{i})-\deg(\mathcal{F}_{i})}{\deg(\mathcal{O}(1))}+1}\rceilm=⌈deg(O(1))2rk(Fi​)g(X)−2rk(Fi​)−deg(Fi​)​+1⌉

and using Lemma 5, Hom(Fi(m−1),ω)=0\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(\mathcal{F}_{i}(m-1),\omega)=0Hom(Fi​(m−1),ω)=0 for all iii. Thus {Fi}\{F_{i}\}{Fi​} is bound. ◻

Dimension 2 case is much more complicated since there is no good estimation for H1(X,F)H^{1}(X,\mathcal{F})H1(X,F). We will show that the family of semistable vector bundle with rank 2 on a smooth surface is bounded. Let XXX be a smooth projective surface and O(1)\mathcal{O}(1)O(1) be a very ample line sheaf. Let F(P)\mathfrak{F}(P)F(P) be the family consists of rank 2 torsion-free semistable sheaf with fixed Hilbert polynomial PPP.

Lemma 33 (Ta13). There are integer n1n_{1}n1​ and n2n_{2}n2​ such that for any F∈F(P)\mathcal{F}\in \mathfrak{F}(P)F∈F(P), there is a subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E of F\mathcal{F}F with n1≤deg⁡(E)≤n2n_{1}\leq \deg(\mathcal{E})\leq n_{2}n1​≤deg(E)≤n2​.

Proof

Proof. First F\mathcal{F}F is semistable so one can set n2=deg⁡(F)2n_{2}=\frac{\deg (\mathcal{F})}{2}n2​=2deg(F)​, then for all rank 1 subsheaf E\mathcal{E}E we have deg⁡(E)≤deg⁡(F)2\deg(\mathcal{E})\leq \frac{\deg (\mathcal{F})}{2}deg(E)≤2deg(F)​.

We can choose n1>0n_{1}>0n1​>0 such that P(F)(n)>0P(\mathcal{F})(n)>0P(F)(n)>0 for all F∈F(P)\mathcal{F}\in \mathfrak{F}(P)F∈F(P). We may also assume deg⁡(F)≥−2n1+2deg⁡(ω)\deg (\mathcal{F})\geq -2n_{1}+2\deg (\omega)deg(F)≥−2n1​+2deg(ω) so deg⁡(Fˇ(−m)⊗ω)<0\deg(\check{\mathcal{F}}(-m)\otimes\omega)<0deg(Fˇ(−m)⊗ω)<0. Note that any global section will induce a morphism OX→Fˇ(−m)⊗ω\mathcal{O}_{X}\to\check{\mathcal{F}}(-m)\otimes\omegaOX​→Fˇ(−m)⊗ω, which contradicts the fact Fˇ(−m)⊗ω\check{\mathcal{F}}(-m)\otimes\omegaFˇ(−m)⊗ω is semistable with negative degree. So

H0(X,Fˇ(−m)⊗ω)=Hom(F(m),ω)=H2(X,F(m))ˇ=0.H^{0}(X,\check{\mathcal{F}}(-m)\otimes\omega)=\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(\mathcal{F}(m),\omega)=H^{2}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))^{\check{}}=0.H0(X,Fˇ(−m)⊗ω)=Hom(F(m),ω)=H2(X,F(m))ˇ=0.

Thus H0(X,F(m))≠0H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(m))\neq 0H0(X,F(m))=0 for all F\mathcal{F}F and a global section induces the morphism OX→F(m)\mathcal{O}_{X}\to \mathcal{F}(m)OX​→F(m). Let the image be G\mathcal{G}G, then deg⁡(G(n1))≥0\deg(\mathcal{G}(n_{1}))\geq 0deg(G(n1​))≥0 and deg⁡(G)≥−n1\deg(\mathcal{G})\geq -n_{1}deg(G)≥−n1​. ◻

Theorem 34. F(P)\mathfrak{F}(P)F(P) is bounded.

Proof

Proof. We will use Theorem 17 to prove this theorem. From Lemma 15 and the definition of Castelnuovo-Mumford regularity, if the family {F(m)∣F∈F(P)}\{\mathcal{F}(m)|\mathcal{F}\in \mathfrak{F}(P)\}{F(m)∣F∈F(P)} is bounded, then F(P)\mathfrak{F}(P)F(P) is bounded. So we may let mmm small enough and assume deg⁡(F)<0\deg(\mathcal{F})<0deg(F)<0 for all F∈F(P)\mathcal{F}\in \mathfrak{F}(P)F∈F(P). Since any nonzero global section of F\mathcal{F}F will induce a morphism OX→F\mathcal{O}_{X}\to \mathcal{F}OX​→F, which will contradict to the assumption F\mathcal{F}F is semistable. Thus H0(X,F)=0H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F})=0H0(X,F)=0 for all F\mathcal{F}F.

For general hyperplane H1H_{1}H1​, H2H_{2}H2​ in the linear system ∣O(1)∣\left| \mathcal{O}(1) \right|∣O(1)∣, h0(F∣H1∩H2)=2deg⁡Xh^{0}(\mathcal{F}|_{H_{1}\cap H_{2}})=2\deg Xh0(F∣H1​∩H2​​)=2degX is bounded.

Now we show h0(F∣H)h^{0}(\mathcal{F}|_{H})h0(F∣H​) is bounded for general hyperplane HHH. According to Lemma 33, there are constants n1n_{1}n1​, n2n_{2}n2​ and a subsheaf E⊂F\mathcal{E}\subset \mathcal{F}E⊂F such that n1≤deg⁡(E)≤n2n_{1}\leq \deg(\mathcal{E})\leq n_{2}n1​≤deg(E)≤n2​. We may assume X∩HX\cap HX∩H is smooth curve and E∣H\mathcal{E}|_{H}E∣H​, (F/E)∣H(\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})|_{H}(F/E)∣H​ are locally free. Let ggg be the genus of X∩HX\cap HX∩H for general HHH. Let n3=deg⁡(F)−n1n_{3}=\deg(\mathcal{F})-n_{1}n3​=deg(F)−n1​, n4=deg⁡(F)−n2n_{4}=\deg(\mathcal{F})-n_{2}n4​=deg(F)−n2​ and n=max⁡{0,2g−n1,2g−n4}n=\max\{0,2g-n_{1},2g-n_{4}\}n=max{0,2g−n1​,2g−n4​}. Then n4≤deg⁡(F/E)≤n3n_{4}\leq \deg(\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})\leq n_{3}n4​≤deg(F/E)≤n3​. Since deg⁡(E∣H)>2g−2\deg(\mathcal{E}|_{H})>2g-2deg(E∣H​)>2g−2 and deg⁡((F/E)∣H)>2g−2\deg ((\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})|_{H})>2g-2deg((F/E)∣H​)>2g−2, h1(E∣H)=0h^{1}(\mathcal{E}|_{H})=0h1(E∣H​)=0 and h1((F/E)∣H)=0h^{1}((\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})|_{H})=0h1((F/E)∣H​)=0. By Riemann-Roch theorem,

h0(E∣H(n))≤n+1−g+n2,h^{0}(\mathcal{E}|_{H}(n))\leq n+1-g+n_{2},h0(E∣H​(n))≤n+1−g+n2​,

h0((F/E)∣H(n))≤n+1−g+deg⁡(F)−n1.h^{0}((\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})|_{H}(n))\leq n+1-g+\deg(\mathcal{F})-n_{1}.h0((F/E)∣H​(n))≤n+1−g+deg(F)−n1​.

So

h0(F∣H)≤h0(E∣H)+h0((F/E)∣H)≤h0(E∣H(n))+h0((F/E)∣H(n))≤2−2g+2n+n2−n1\begin{aligned} h^{0}(\mathcal{F}|_{H})&\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{E}|_{H})+h^{0}((\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})|_{H})\\ &\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{E}|_{H}(n))+h^{0}((\mathcal{F}/\mathcal{E})|_{H}(n))\\ &\leq 2-2g+2n+n_{2}-n_{1}\end{aligned}h0(F∣H​)​≤h0(E∣H​)+h0((F/E)∣H​)≤h0(E∣H​(n))+h0((F/E)∣H​(n))≤2−2g+2n+n2​−n1​​

is bounded. ◻

In higher dimensional, the traditional approach for boundedness won’t work when the base field is of positive characteristic. Theorem 21, Lemma 23 and Theorem 50 strongly depend on the assumption of characteristic. The problem in positive characteristic case is completely solved by Langer in his recent work Langer8.

In fact, Gieseker provided a counter-example for Lemma 23 in positive characteristic in Ge2: Assume the base field has characteristic ppp. Let F:X→XF:X\to XF:X→X be the absolute Frobenius morphism, i.e. the morphism which is an identity on topological space and sends x↦xpx\mapsto x^{p}x↦xp on OX\mathcal{O}_{X}OX​.

Example 35 (Ge2). Let ppp be any positive integer and g≥2g\geq 2g≥2, then there is a curve XXX of genus ggg over a field of characteristic ppp, and a semistable bundle E\mathcal{E}E of rank 2 on XXX, such that F∗EF^{*}\mathcal{E}F∗E is not semistable.

The argument using ampleness does not work in positive characteristic case either. To make result similar to Lemma 25, Langer introduced strongly semistable in Langer8.

Definition 36. A coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F in characteristic ppp is strongly semistable if (Fn)∗F(F^{n})^{*}\mathcal{F}(Fn)∗F is semistable for all n≥0n\geq 0n≥0.

Langer showed in terms of strongly semistable, the tensor product of strongly semistable sheaves is still strongly semistable. He also improved the Bogomolov inequality and restriction theorems to general characteristic case and used them to show the boundness for family of sheaves with upper bound in μmax\mu_{max}μmax​.

There are several types restriction theorem for general characteristic case. For example, Mehta and Ramanathan proved their restriction theorem:

Theorem 37 (Mehta, Ramanathan). Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension n≥2n\geq 2n≥2 and let O(1)\mathcal{O}(1)O(1) be a very ample line sheaf. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a semistable sheaf. Then there is an integer a0a_{0}a0​ such that for all a≥a0a\geq a_{0}a≥a0​ there is an open dense subset Ua⊂∣O(a)∣U_{a}\subset \left| \mathcal{O}(a) \right|Ua​⊂∣O(a)∣ such that for all D∈UaD\in U_{a}D∈Ua​ the divisor DDD is smooth and E∣DE|_{D}E∣D​ is semistable.

However, we cannot directly apply this theorem to prove the boundedness. Maruyama showed a theorem that improves a0a_{0}a0​ to 1 when the rank of sheaves is small in Ma10:

Theorem 38. Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension n≥2n\geq 2n≥2 and let O(1)\mathcal{O}(1)O(1) be a very ample line sheaf. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a torsion-free semistable sheaf on XXX and rk(F)<dim⁡X\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})<\dim Xrk(F)<dimX. Then for general hyperplane section HHH in ∣O(1)∣\left| \mathcal{O}(1) \right|∣O(1)∣, the restriction F∣H\mathcal{F}|_{H}F∣H​ is semistable.

Maruyama proved boundedness of semistable bundles of rank 2 with fixed Hilbert polynomial on smooth projective varieties using the above theorem. See Ma10 for more details.

Results from Descent Theory

In this section we introduce some basic results from descent of quasicoherent sheaves. We need faithfully flat descent and Galois descent in the Theorem 21 and Lemma 23. The proof of theorems in this section will be omitted and we refer chapter 14 Grotz&We3 and Stacks[0238]1 for details.

Let p:S′→Sp:S'\to Sp:S′→S be a faithfully flat quasicompact morphism of schemes. Let S′′=S′×SS′S''=S'\times_{S}S'S′′=S′×S​S′ and S′′′=S′×SS′×SS′′S'''=S'\times_{S}S'\times_{S}S''S′′′=S′×S​S′×S​S′′ and the projections be pi:S′′→S′p_{i}:S''\to S'pi​:S′′→S′ and pij:S′′′→S′′p_{ij}:S'''\to S''pij​:S′′′→S′′.

Definition 39. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a quasicoherent sheaf on S′S'S′. A descent datum of F\mathcal{F}F is a OS′\mathcal{O}_{S'}OS′​-module morphism φ:p1∗F→≃p2∗F\varphi:p_{1}^{*}\mathcal{F}\xrightarrow{\simeq}p_{2}^{*}\mathcal{F}φ:p1∗​F≃​p2∗​F satisfying the cocycle condition

p23∗φ∘p12∗φ=p13∗φ,p_{23}^{*}\varphi\circ p_{12}^{*}\varphi=p_{13}^{*}\varphi, p23∗​φ∘p12∗​φ=p13∗​φ,

i.e. φ\varphiφ makes the following diagram commutes:

We can define the category Qcoh(S′/S)\mathrm{Qcoh}(S' /S)Qcoh(S′/S) of quasicoherent sheaves on S′S'S′ with the descent datum. More precisely, the object of Qcoh(S′/S)\mathrm{Qcoh}(S' /S)Qcoh(S′/S) is pair (F,φ)(\mathcal{F},\varphi)(F,φ) the quasicoherent sheaves on S′S'S′ with descent datum φ\varphiφ. The morphism from (F,φ)(\mathcal{F},\varphi)(F,φ) to (G,ψ)(\mathcal{G},\psi)(G,ψ) is a morphism of OS′\mathcal{O}_{S}'OS′​-modules u:F→Gu:\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{G}u:F→G such that p2∗u∘φ=ψ∘p1∗up_{2}^{*}u\circ \varphi=\psi \circ p_{1}^{*}up2∗​u∘φ=ψ∘p1∗​u.

Let Φ:Qcoh(S)→Qcoh(S′/S)\Phi:\mathrm{Qcoh}(S)\to \mathrm{Qcoh}(S' /S)Φ:Qcoh(S)→Qcoh(S′/S) be a functor which maps F\mathcal{F}F to p∗Fp^{*}\mathcal{F}p∗F and give rise to a canonical datum φ:p1∗(p∗F)→≃p2∗(p∗F)\varphi:p_{1}^{*}(p^{*}\mathcal{F})\xrightarrow{\simeq}p_{2}^{*}(p^{*}\mathcal{F})φ:p1∗​(p∗F)≃​p2∗​(p∗F).

Theorem 40. Φ:Qcoh(S)→Qcoh(S′/S)\Phi:\mathrm{Qcoh}(S)\to \mathrm{Qcoh}(S' /S)Φ:Qcoh(S)→Qcoh(S′/S) defines an equivalence of categories.

Next we study a specific case of faithfully flat descent, using the action of a Galois group. Let GGG be a finite group and SSS a scheme. We can view ∐g∈GS\coprod\limits_{g\in G}Sg∈G∐​S as the constant group scheme over SSS: It represents the functor that associate SSS-scheme TTT with the locally constant map T→GT\to GT→G. Denote the group scheme ∐g∈G\coprod\limits_{g\in G}g∈G∐​ by GSG_{S}GS​. The multiplication μ:GS×SGS→GS\mu:G_{S}\times_{S}G_{S}\to G_{S}μ:GS​×S​GS​→GS​ is given by transportation of TTT-points in each component. An action of GSG_{S}GS​ on a SSS-scheme S′S'S′ by SSS-automorphism is a morphism σ:GS×SS′→S′\sigma: G_{S}\times_{S} S'\to S'σ:GS​×S​S′→S′, σ:(g,s′)↦gs′\sigma:(g,s')\mapsto gs'σ:(g,s′)↦gs′ in TTT-points.

Definition 41. Let p2:GS×SS′→S′p_{2}:G_{S}\times_{S}S'\to S'p2​:GS​×S​S′→S′ be the projection on the section component. A GSG_{S}GS​-equinvariant structure on quasicoherent OS\mathcal{O}_{S}OS​-module F\mathcal{F}F is an isomorphism φ:σ∗F→≃p2∗F\varphi:\sigma^{*}\mathcal{F}\xrightarrow{\simeq} p_{2}^{*}\mathcal{F}φ:σ∗F≃​p2∗​F satisfying the cocycle condition

p23∗φ∘(idGS×σ)∗φ=(μ×idS′)φ.p_{23}^{*}\varphi \circ (id_{G_{S}}\times \sigma)^{*}\varphi=(\mu\times id_{S'})\varphi. p23∗​φ∘(idGS​​×σ)∗φ=(μ×idS′​)φ.

Definition 42. A Galois covering with Galois group GSG_{S}GS​ is a faithfully flat morphism p:S→Sp:S\to Sp:S→S with a GSG_{S}GS​-action on S′S'S′ by SSS-automorphism such that the morphism GS×SS′→S′×SS′G_{S}\times_{S}S'\to S'\times_{S} S'GS​×S​S′→S′×S​S′ which on TTT-points (g,s′)↦(s′,gs′)(g,s')\mapsto (s',gs')(g,s′)↦(s′,gs′) is an isomorphism.

Moreover, if f:Y→Xf:Y\to Xf:Y→X is a finite morphism of normal projective schemes with K(Y)K(Y)K(Y) Galois over K(X)K(X)K(X), then fff is a Galois covering.

Let S′→SS'\to SS′→S be a Galois covering. We can define the GSG_{S}GS​-equinvariant quasicoherent sheaf category QcohG(S′/S)\mathrm{Qcoh}_{G}(S' /S)QcohG​(S′/S): The objects in QcohG(S′/S)\mathrm{Qcoh}_{G}(S' /S)QcohG​(S′/S) are pairs (F,φ)(\mathcal{F},\varphi)(F,φ) of quasicoherent sheaves on S′S'S′ with GSG_{S}GS​-equinvariant structure. A morphism from (F,φ)(\mathcal{F},\varphi)(F,φ) to (G,ψ)(\mathcal{G},\psi)(G,ψ) are OS′\mathcal{O}_{S'}OS′​-morphism u:F→Gu:\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{G}u:F→G such that ψ∘σ∗u=p2∗u∘φ\psi\circ \sigma^{*}u=p_{2}^{*}u\circ \varphiψ∘σ∗u=p2∗​u∘φ.

Similarly, we can define a functor Φ:Qcoh(S)→QcohG(S′/S)\Phi:\mathrm{Qcoh}(S)\to \mathrm{Qcoh}_{G}(S' /S)Φ:Qcoh(S)→QcohG​(S′/S) which maps F\mathcal{F}F to p∗p^{*}p∗ and gives rise to canonical GSG_{S}GS​-equinvariant structure p2∗p∗F→≃σ∗p∗Fp_{2}^{*}p^{*}\mathcal{F}\xrightarrow{\simeq}\sigma^{*}p^{*}\mathcal{F}p2∗​p∗F≃​σ∗p∗F.

Theorem 43. Φ:Qcoh(S)→QcohG(S′/S)\Phi:\mathrm{Qcoh}(S)\to \mathrm{Qcoh}_{G}(S' /S)Φ:Qcoh(S)→QcohG​(S′/S) defines an equivalence of categories.

Ample Vector Bundles

We will summarize the important relation between ample sheaf and positive degree sheaf in this section. The original reference for this section is Ha5, and we will mainly refer Ha5 and La9 for the proofs.

Let XXX be a smooth projective variety over algebraically closed field kkk, E\mathcal{E}E is a vector bundle on XXX and π:P(E)→X\pi:\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{E})\to Xπ:P(E)→X be the projective bundle associated to E\mathcal{E}E. Denote the tautological line sheaf on P(E)\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{E})P(E) by Oπ(1)\mathcal{O}_{\pi}(1)Oπ​(1).

Definition 44. E\mathcal{E}E is ample if Oπ(1)\mathcal{O}_{\pi}(1)Oπ​(1) is ample;

E\mathcal{E}E is nef if Oπ(1)\mathcal{O}_{\pi}(1)Oπ​(1) is nef.

The following proposition is straight from definition.

Proposition 45. Let E\mathcal{E}E be an ample (nef) vector bundle on XXX, then for any quotient F\mathcal{F}F of E\mathcal{E}E, F\mathcal{F}F is ample (nef).

Theorem 46. Let E\mathcal{E}E be a vector bundle on XXX, then the followings are equivalent:

  1. E\mathcal{E}E is ample.

  2. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, there is an integer m(F)m(\mathcal{F})m(F) such that Hi(X,SmE⊗F)=0H^{i}(X,S^{m}\mathcal{E}\otimes \mathcal{F})=0Hi(X,SmE⊗F)=0 for all i>0i>0i>0 and m≥m(F)m\geq m(\mathcal{F})m≥m(F).

  3. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, there is an integer n(F)n(\mathcal{F})n(F) such that SnE⊗FS^{n}\mathcal{E}\otimes\mathcal{F}SnE⊗F is generated by global sections for all n≥n(F)n\geq n(\mathcal{F})n≥n(F).

Using above theorem, one can show that:

Proposition 47. Let 0→E′→E→E′′→00\to \mathcal{E}'\to \mathcal{E}\to \mathcal{E}''\to 00→E′→E→E′′→0 be an exact sequence of vector bundles on XXX. If E′\mathcal{E}'E′ and E′′\mathcal{E}''E′′ are ample, then so is E\mathcal{E}E.

Proposition 48. Let E\mathcal{E}E be a vector bundle on XXX, then the followings are equivalent:

  1. E\mathcal{E}E is ample.

  2. SkES^{k}\mathcal{E}SkE is ample for some k≥1k\geq 1k≥1.

  3. SkES^{k}\mathcal{E}SkE is ample for all k≥1k\geq 1k≥1.

Corollary 49. Assume E\mathcal{E}E and F\mathcal{F}F are ample vector bundles on XXX. Then E⊗F\mathcal{E}\otimes\mathcal{F}E⊗F is ample.

All propositions above are still true on varieties over kkk with positive characteristic.

Theorem 50. Assume kkk is algebraically closed field with characteristic zero. Let XXX be a projective curve over kkk and E\mathcal{E}E be a semistable vector bundle of over XXX. Then

  1. E\mathcal{E}E is nef if and only if deg⁡(E)≥0\deg(\mathcal{E})\geq 0deg(E)≥0;

  2. E\mathcal{E}E is ample if and only if deg⁡(E)>0\deg(\mathcal{E})> 0deg(E)>0.

The assumption chark=0\mathop{\mathrm{char}}k=0chark=0 is required in Theorem 50. In fact, Serre constructed a non-singular curve XXX of genus 3 over a field of characteristic 3, and a vector bundle E\mathcal{E}E of rank 2 with deg⁡(E)=1\deg(\mathcal{E})=1deg(E)=1, while all the quotient of E\mathcal{E}E has positive degree but not ample. See La4 for the example.
